questions.text: Most common organ that herniates in Morgagni’s hernia is ______
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the most common herniating structure in a Morgagni hernia.

Morgagni Hernia:

  • A hernia in the anterior part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments
  • The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

Morgagni hernia:

questions.text: You are using Haase's rule for the estimation of fetal age in a pregnant woman. Which of the following parameters is used here?
questions.solution:
Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in lunar months from its crown-heel length (in cm).

According to the rule:

  • When the crown heel length ≤ 25 cm, Age in months = Square root of crown heel length
  • When the crown heel length > 25 cm, Age in months = crown heel length divided by 5

Note: Haase’s modification of Morrison‘s law states that during the last 5 months, the length in centimeters divided by 5 gives the age in months.

Eg : crown heel length = 30 cm, gestaional age = 6 months.

questions.text: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100 mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes. 

First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity, neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia.

First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy:

  • Insulin
  • Glyburide 
  • Metformin

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the OPD with a sore throat and a rash, which appears as shown in the image, for the past 2 days. The rash started around the neck and then spread to the trunk and extremities. On examination, rash blanches on pressure. Tongue examination shows swollen papillae. Which of the following toxins is responsible for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scarlet fever, which is caused by a pyrogenic exotoxin produced by Group A streptococcus (GAS).

In scarlet fever, the rash appears within 24–48 hours of the onset of upper respiratory infections. It begins around the head and neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities. It usually spares palms, and soles. It is a diffuse, papular, and erythematous eruption, which blanches on pressure. The cheeks are erythematous, with pallor around the mouth. The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

The image below shows a strawberry tongue.

questions.text: A trucut biopsy is obtained from a woman who presented with a breast lump. The biopsy confirms the presence of mucinous carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry shows ER, PR and HER2/neu positive.  What is the molecular subtype of breast cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer with ER, PR +ve and HER2/neu +ve status will be classified as luminal B type. It is also known as triple-positive cancer. 

Along with ER, PR, and HER2/neu, a proliferation index known as the Ki67 index is also used.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with a twin pregnancy was admitted for normal delivery. After medical induction of labor, she started to bleed profusely from her rectum, vagina, and IV sites. She became hypotensive, tachycardic, and pulses were feeble. Which of the following laboratory findings will you see in her case?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient seems to have disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) due to amniotic fluid embolism following medical induction of labor. 

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a condition characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation. The central mechanism is the uncontrolled generation of thrombin by exposure of blood to pathologic levels of tissue factor.

Lab abnormalities in DIC:

  • Low platelet count
  • Low fibrinogen
  • Prolonged PT and aPTT
  • Increased D-dimer
  • Increased fibrin-degradation products
  • Decreased protein C
  • Decreased antithrombin III
  • Increased thrombin-antithrombin complex

questions.text: Which of the following is the biomedical concept of disease based upon?

choices.text: Combination of social, economic and political influences

questions.solution:
The biomedical concept of disease is based on the germ theory of disease, which was postulated by Louis Pasteur.

The germ theory of disease states that microorganisms known as pathogens or germs can lead to disease. It was criticized that it did not include environmental, social, psychological, and cultural determinants of health.  

The ecological concept of disease states that disease is the maladjustment of the human organism to the environment.

The psychosocial concept of disease hypothesised that health is also influenced by social, psychological, cultural and economic factors as well.

The holistic concept of disease includes all the above concepts to describe health.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is NADPH. The most important source of NADPH is the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway.

The HMP shunt pathway, or pentose phosphate pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It generates NADPH and synthesizes ribose. NADP+ is hydrogenated to NADPH by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. Since the HMP shunt pathway and de novo fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. Thus, this forms the major source for NADPH for fatty acid synthesis. 

Other minor sources of NADPH are extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase and NADP malate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme).

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urine stream and frequent urination in small amounts for the past month. He also mentions that he often feels lightheaded and has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin should be given to this patient as it has the least effect on blood pressure. 

It is an α-blocker that has more selectivity towards α1A/1D when compared to α1B receptors. The vasodilatory effects are mainly attributed to the blockade of α1B receptors present on blood vessels.

The relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to the blockade of α1A receptors present predominantly in the prostatic stroma. It lacks the apoptotic effect on prostatic cells that is seen with terazosin and doxazosin.

questions.text: A neonate was brought to the emergency room with lethargy and failure to thrive. A microscopic image of his hair strand is shown below. Which of the given enzymes may be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given microscopy image shows trichorrhexis nodosa and longitudinal breaks and is seen in argininosuccinic aciduria. This occurs due to a defect in the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

Trichorrhexis nodosa is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. It can also be caused by other disorders such as hypothyroidism, iron deficiency and Menkes' kinky hair syndrome

questions.text: What type of cell is the lupus erythematosus cell?
questions.solution:
The lupus erythematosus (LE) cell is a phagocytic neutrophil or macrophage.

Nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous to produce LE bodies or hematoxylin bodies. Phagocytic neutrophils or macrophages engulf the denatured nucleus of an injured cell. Demonstration of LE cells in vitro was used in the past for the diagnosis of SLE.

The image below shows a lupus erythematosus (LE) cell.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents to the casualty with symptoms of acute-onset breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, and nausea. Physical examination and laboratory workup were unremarkable. Which of the following best explains the episode?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a classic panic attack.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort (arises de novo without any stressor). Recurrent panic attacks are termed as panic disorder.

Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

The differential diagnosis for panic attacks:

  1. Angina, MI
  2. Mitral valve prolapse
  3. Asthma
  4. Pulmonary embolus
  5. Pheochromocytoma
  6. Hyperthyroidism (Grave's disease)
  7. Epilepsy
  8. Amphetamine and anticholinergic drugs
  9. Withdrawal symptoms

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following regions promotes a 'sense of reward' in human beings?
questions.solution:
Major reward centres are located along the course of the medial forebrain bundle, especially in the lateral and ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus. Therefore, stimulation of those areas will promote a sense of reward. 

It is interesting to note that in the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus, a weak stimulus produces a sense of pleasure whereas a strong stimulus produces rage. This phenomenon occurs in many areas where a weak stimulus produces a sense of reward while stronger ones produce a sense of punishment.

questions.text: After a fatty meal, which of the following lipoproteins are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency?
questions.solution:
After a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols).

This is called a nascent chylomicron which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL is remodeled into mature chylomicron.

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy.

Clinical correlate: Patients with lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II deficiency (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) hence show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma, after a fatty meal.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products?
questions.solution:
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments. 

Enzymatic digestion of antibody with Papain, Pepsin and Mercaptoethanol produces fragments as follows: 

a) Papain: 2 Fab fragments and one Fc fragment
b) Pepsin: One F(ab’)2 fragment and many smaller fragments
c) Mercaptoethanol: 2 H and 2 L chains

questions.text: What is the most common cause of male infertility?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of male infertility is disorders of spermatogenesis.

Male factor is the cause of infertility in about 20% of infertile couples. However, it is a contributing factor for infertility in 50% of cases.

questions.text: Phototherapy is a treatment for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Phototherapy was introduced as a treatment for seasonal affective disorder.

In this disorder, patients typically experience depression as the photoperiod of the day decreases with advancing winter. 

Phototherapy typically involves exposing the affected patient to bright light in the range of 1,500 to 10,000 lux or more, typically with a lightbox. The patient sits in front of this lightbox for approximately 1 to 2 hours before dawn each day.

questions.text: Human cardiac muscle contains ________.
questions.solution:
Human heart contains both alpha and beta isoforms of the myosin heavy chain. β isoform has a lower myosin ATPase activity than the α isoform. 

  • α isoform predominates in the adult atria.
  • β isoform predominates in the adult ventricles.
  • The spatial distribution contributes to the well coordinated contraction of the heart.

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is caused by the mutation of the transthyretin protein?
questions.solution:
Familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy (FAP) is associated with the deposition of mutant transthyretin protein (TTR). 

FAP is an autosomal dominant condition. The deposition occurs as amyloid fibrils in peripheral and autonomic nerves. Mutated TTR is prone to misfolding and aggregation, and shows resistance to proteolysis.

Systemic senile amyloidosis (amyloid of aging) refers to the systemic deposition of normal TTR amyloid in elderly patients. Symptomatic patients present with restrictive cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias. Another rare form affecting predominantly the heart results from the deposition of a mutant form of TTR.

Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autosomal-recessive condition seen in individuals of Mediterranean descent (Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic). The affected gene encodes a protein called pyrin, which is involved in cytokine production. The amyloid fibril proteins in this condition are made up of AA proteins. It presents with attacks of fever and serositis. 

Isolated atrial amyloidosis is associated with AANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) amyloid deposition

questions.text: Patients with hairy-cell leukemia are at a higher risk of infection with which of the following?
questions.solution: Hairy cell leukemia is associated with infections of Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare. This is possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Among them, infection with Mycobacterium kansasii is common.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady came to the clinic with complaints of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange peel-like appearance, also called as peau d’orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is the hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma.

Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin.

Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction.

Cancer-en-cuirasse is an aggressive form of cancer, where there is cutaneous and subcutaneous infiltration of the cancer cells.

Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

A three-year-old should normally be able to walk upstairs with alternate feet.

questions.text: The approach shown in the image is a part of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Detect – Treat – Prevent – Build approach for eliminating TB in India is part of the National Strategic Plan for TB (2017-2025). The components of this approach are:

  • Detect - Early identification of presumptive TB cases, at the first point of care, be it private or public sectors, and prompt diagnosis using high sensitivity diagnostic tests.
  • Treat - Provide sustained, equitable access to high quality TB treatment, care and support services.
  • Prevent - Prevent the emergence of TB in susceptible populations.
  • Build - Undertake critical management reforms, restructuring of HR and financial norms, pathways for private sector participation, in order to improve efficiency, effectiveness.

questions.text: In a patient with uncontrolled diabetes, what is the value of plasma clearance of glucose?
questions.solution:
In uncontrolled diabetes, the plasma clearance of glucose is greater than zero. 

Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

Clearance of different substances can be shown in a graph as follows: 

The above graph depicts renal handling of glucose, inulin, and para-aminohippurate (PAH) and can be explained as follows:

Glucose clearance: Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

Inulin clearance: Inulin is freely filtered and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted. Hence, it is constant and equal to the glomerular filtration rate.

PAH clearance: PAH is both filtered and secreted. When plasma PAH is low, clearance is high. However, as plasma PAH rises above the threshold level for PAH secretion, clearance falls progressively.

questions.solution:

questions.text: You are studying the literacy rate of a community with a total population of 10000. Out of these, there are 2000 children from 0-6 years of age, and 4000 literate individuals above 7 years of age. What is the effective literacy rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The effective literacy rate of this population is 50%. 

It is calculated as follows,

Effective literacy rate = (Number of literate persons aged 7 and above x 100) / population aged 7 and above in a given year. 

In the given scenario, people aged 7 years and above = 10000 - 2000 = 8000. Out of these 8000 people, 4000 are literate.

Thus, effective literacy rate = 4000 x 100/8000 = 50%.

Related Pearl: Literacy Rates

Literacy rate

  • The literacy rate in India currently is 74.04%
  • According to the 2011 census, Kerala has the highest literacy rate among Indian states with a value of 93.91%

questions.text: A 25-year-old diabetic woman presents to the OPD with the following skin lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.

It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus.

The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central ulceration.

Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning rash that appears as shown below.

Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as pigmented pretibial papules as shown below.

Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain.
questions.solution:
The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45o) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species.

Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear conidia in chains. Long aseptate conidiophores (specialised conidia-bearing hyphae) are seen with terminal vesicles. Phialides (vase-shaped cells producing conidia) with conidia are arranged in basipetal chains on the terminal vesicle. The following image shows the lactophenol cotton blue solution (LPCB) mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.

Option A: Mucor produces nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium.

Option B: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores.

Option D: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: In lardaceous spleen, deposition of amyloid occurs in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Lardaceous spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in sinusoids of the red pulp.

Sago spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in splenic follicles (white pulp).

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is ansa cervicalis and thyrohyoid is not supplied by it. Thyrohyoid is supplied by the C1 fibers through the hypoglossal nerve.

The muscles supplied by ansa cervicalis are:

  • Sternothyroid
  • Sternohyoid
  • Omohyoid both inferior and superior belly

The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop embedded in the anterior wall of the carotid sheath. It is formed by two roots:

  • The superior root is a continuation of the descending branch of the hypoglossal nerve. It is derived from the 1st cervical nerve (C1) and supplies the superior belly of the omohyoid.
  • The inferior root is derived from the 2nd and 3rd cervical spinal nerves (C2, C3).

questions.text: You are performing the test shown in the image on a patient. How many days later do you ask the patient to return so that you get an accurate read on the Mitsuda reaction?
questions.solution:
Mitsuda's reaction is read in the 3rd week, i.e., on the 21st day or 20 days after the day of injection.

Lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. It is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just under the skin.

The first reaction to occur is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours. It usually remains for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance. The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. On the 21st day, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. 

Note: The 21st day is 20 days after the day of injection which is counted as the 1st day.

questions.text: The radiograph of a boy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a champagne glass pelvis and is suggestive of achondroplasia.

Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder resulting in proximal limb shortening (rhizomelic dwarfism). It is the most common cause of disproportionate dwarfism. The iliac blades are flattened giving rise to a pelvic inlet that resembles a champagne glass. The acetabular angles are flattened (horizontal) and the sacrosciatic notch is small.

The image below shows a patient with achondroplasia -

Other options: 

Option A: Perthe's disease is characterized by a flattened and later, fragmented femoral head. 

Option B: Hip dysplasia usually presents with hip dislocation. 

Option C: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) presents with the metaphysis being displaced laterally and not overlapping the posterior lip of the acetabulum as it should normally.

questions.text: A baseball player presented with right upper arm pain. He started experiencing pain after he threw a ball and felt a pop. An upper arm X-ray was done and is given below. What is this fracture known as?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows a displaced spiral fracture of the humerus at the junction of the middle-third and distal-third. This is known as Holstein-Lewis fracture.

There is a high risk of entrapment of the radial nerve in the bone fragments of this fracture. Hence this fracture is associated with radial nerve injury (wrist drop).

questions.text: What is specific compliance of lung?
questions.solution:
Specific compliance is obtained by dividing compliance by functional residual capacity.

Types of compliance:

  • Static compliance: It is measured at rest.
  • Dynamic compliance: It is measured during breathing. It considers airflow resistance or impedance into account. It is maximum in medium-sized bronchi.
  • Specific compliance: 
    • Lung compliance is volume-dependent. 
    • It is greater at low lung volumes than at high lung volumes. For this reason, the term specific compliance is often used to denote compliance with reference to the original lung volume.
  • The total compliance of a normal person near the normal end-expiratory lung volume (functional residual capacity [FRC]) is about 0.1 L/cm H2O.
  • The compliance of the lungs is about 0.2 L/cm H2O.

Applied aspect:

In case of emphysema, compliance is increased but specific compliance decreases (because FRC is severely elevated).

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of nephron development in order from the earlier stage to the later stage.

1. Blastema stage
2. Comma 'C' stage
3. S-shaped stage
4. Vesicle stage
questions.solution:
The correct order of the stages of development of the nephron from earlier to later is blastema stage --> vesicle stage --> comma 'C' stage --> S-shaped stage.

The tip of the ureteric bud, which is growing towards the metanephric blastema, becomes dilated to form an ampulla. The ampulla induces the cells of the metanephric blastema to develop into a nephron.

The cells of the metanephric blastema pass through the following stages when developing into a nephron:

questions.text: Which tricyclic antidepressant has an additional dopaminergic receptor antagonist action?
questions.solution:
The tricyclic antidepressant having an additional dopaminergic receptor antagonist action is amoxapine.

Tricyclic antidepressants block the transporter of norepinephrine (NET) and serotonin (SERT) thereby preventing their uptake. Some of the TCA additionally block other receptors like alpha 1, H1, and M1.

  • TCA blocking NET selectively - desipramine, nortriptyline, amoxapine.
  • TCA blocking both NET and SERT equally - imipramine, amitriptyline.

Clomipramine, doxepin, and imipramine are tertiary amines and do not possess any dopaminergic antagonist effect.

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive index of recent transmission of malaria?
questions.solution:
The infant parasite rate is regarded as the most sensitive index for recent transmission of malaria in a locality.

It is defined as the % of infants showing malarial parasites in their blood films. The transmission of malaria is considered absent if the infant parasite rate is zero for 3 consecutive years in a locality (even though the Anopheline vectors responsible for the previous transmission may remain).

questions.text: What is the single most important galactopoetic hormone in post-natal women?
questions.solution:
Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone in postnatal women.

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (ductal growth)

Progesterone (alveolar growth)
Lactogenesis Initiation of milk secretion Prolactin
Galactokinesis Ejection of milk Oxytocin
Galactopoiesis Maintainence of lactation Prolactin

questions.text: Artery passing through the structure marked in the diagram below is a branch of:
questions.solution:
The image shown is the ligament of head of the femur and the artery passing through it is the foveal artery/ artery of ligament of head of femur. It is derived from the acetabular branch of obturator artery.

The blood supply of the femoral head is derived from an arterial ring (trochanteric anastomosis) around the neck of femur constituted by:

  • Medial circumflex femoral arteries 
  • Lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Superior and inferior gluteal vessels (minor contributions)

questions.text: During rounds in the postnatal ward, you notice a patient's case sheet mentioning she had uterine tachysystole following labor induction. What is the criteria for this diagnosis?

choices.text: More than  5 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 5 contractions in a 10-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 10-min period

questions.solution:
Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10 min period and may occur in spontaneous or stimulated labor. It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal heart rate abnormalities. Tachysystole interrupts maternal blood flow to the placenta during contractions and may lead to a reduction in fetal oxygenation. It is also associated with placental abruption.

It is caused by pharmacological agents used for cervical ripening and induction such as misoprostol (both oral and vaginal) and dinoprostone. Management includes stopping oxytocin infusion and terbutaline 0.25 mg SC.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the areas marked in the given image?

choices.text: A is a type of association fiber
C is content of interpeduncular fossa
D is devoid of blood brain barrier

questions.solution:
A is anterior commissure, which is a type of commissural fiber, not association fiber.

B is lamina terminalis

C is the mamillary body and is a content of interpeduncular fossa.

D is the pineal gland, which does not have blood-brain barrier.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: D-Tubocurarine acts as a skeletal muscle relaxant by

choices.text: Inhibiting nicotinic receptors at autonomic ganglia
Inhibiting muscarinic receptors at autonomic ganglia
Inhibiting nicotinic receptors at myoneural junction

questions.solution: D-Tubocurarine acts as a skeletal muscle relaxant by inhibiting nicotinic receptors at the myoneural junction (neuromuscular junction). D-tubocurarine is a competitive blocker of acetylcholine (non-depolarising muscle relaxant). It has an affinity towards nicotinic cholinergic receptors at the myoneural junction and no intrinsic activity.

questions.text: What should the Aedes aegypti index be to ensure almost zero risk of yellow fever spread?
questions.solution:
There is no risk of spread of yellow fever if the Aedes aegypti index remains below 1%. 

Aedes aegypti Index: It is defined as the percentage of houses and their premises in a limited well-defined area showing actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child has been recurrently hospitalized for infections, since 2 years of age. After a detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome was suspected. All of the following are components of the Kartagener triad except _____.
questions.solution:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad.

Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesiacharacterized by the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.

As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. Its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.

Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).

questions.text: Yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is the ___________.
questions.solution:
The yoke muscle of the Right lateral rectus in right dextroversion is the left medial rectus.

Yoke muscles also known as contralateral synergists include a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contract simultaneously during version movements.

Versions are simultaneous movements of both eyes in the same direction, such as dextroversion in which both the eyes move to the right.

Hence, in dextroversion, the right eye is in abduction due to the action of right lateral rectus and the left eye is in adduction by the action of the left medial rectus.

An easy method to determine yoke muscle pairs:

Just take the opposite of each word-

Left  → Right

Superior → Inferior

Oblique → Rectus

“Left SO and Right IR” are a yoke muscle pair.

Other examples of yoke muscles are:

  • Right MR and Left LR for levoversion
  • Right IO and Left SR - Levoelevation
  • Right SR and Left IO - Dextroelevation
  • Right IR and Left SO - Dextrodepression

[IO-inferior oblique;SO-superior oblique;SR-superior rectus;IR-inferior rectus;MR-medial rectus;LR-lateral rectus]

questions.text: What is the most common type of vaginal cancer likely to be seen in a woman with a history of intrauterine di-ethyl stilbesterol exposure?
questions.solution:
Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is commonly seen in adoloscent girls with a history of intrauterine DES exposure. 

It involves the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Radical hysterectomy, vaginectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy is the treatment of choice. 

The most common lesion due to DES exposure is vaginal adenosis and not clear cell adenocarcinoma. It is a benign condition.

questions.text:
McNaughten's rule falls under which Section?

BNS- Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita
BNSS- Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita
questions.solution:
McNaughten's rule falls under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (IPC 84). 

It states, "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

Defect: In Mc Naughthen’s rule, only intellectual factors are considered but emotions, delusion, and control of impulses are ignored.

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

 18

-

Not liable

If done by accident or misfortune and without any criminal intention or knowledge in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means and with proper care and caution.

 20

82

A child under 7 years is not liable for the act.

21

83

Child of 7–12 years if not attained proper mental maturity is not liable for the act.

22

84  

McNaughten's rule: A person of unsound mind is not liable for the act.

23

85

A person who under involuntary intoxication has commited an act is not liable for the act.

24

86

A person who under voluntary intoxication commits an act is liable for the act.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for follow-up. His wife states that recently he is forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the antitubercular drug that is implicated in the causation of transient memory loss.

Neurological toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and seizures can occur with isoniazid therapy. It is also associated with abnormalities like:

  • Euphoria
  • Transient memory loss
  • Separation of ideas and reality
  • Loss of self-control
  • Florid psychosis

Pyridoxine therapy can prevent and reverse most of the neurological toxicity and mental abnormalities.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: Oval cells are seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Oval cells refer to stem cells in the liver. They are located in the canals of Hering.

Regeneration of the liver occurs by two major mechanisms:

  • Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes - occurs following partial hepatectomy (resection of up to 90% of the liver can be corrected by this mechanism) 
  • Repopulation from progenitor cells (oval cells) - occurs following chronic liver injury or inflammation

questions.text: A patient presents with mental confusion, visual and auditory hallucinations, perceived changes of body shape, swelling of the tongue, and a fear of impending death after he was treated for primary chancre of syphilis with an intramuscular injection. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has Hoigne Syndrome as he developed acute psychotic symptoms after intramuscular administration of penicillin G for the treatment of syphilis.

Hoigne syndrome:

  • Acute psychotic symptoms due to a pseudoanaphylactic or pseudoallergic reaction that occurs after intramuscular administration of penicillin G procaine or benzathine.
  • These are usually embolic toxic reactions possibly due to vascular occlusion by large crystals of the penicillin salts. It is not due to Penicillin allergy. 
  • The patient presents with mental confusion, visual and auditory hallucinations, perceived changes of body shape, swelling of the tongue and a fear of impending death.

A Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is a reaction to endotoxin-like products released by the death of harmful micro-organisms within the body following antibiotic treatment.

questions.text: Adrenaline is used to treat histamine-induced bronchoconstriction in a patient with brittle asthma. What is this type of antagonism called?
questions.solution:
Adrenaline and histamine are physiological antagonists. 

Adrenaline and histamine act on bronchial muscles. Histamine acts on H1 receptors and produces bronchoconstriction. Adrenaline acts on β2 receptors and produces bronchodilation. Two drugs acting on different receptors and resulting in opposite responses means having pharmacological effects in the opposite direction. This is called physiological antagonism or functional antagonism.

Option B: Chemical antagonism refers to a reaction between two chemicals to neutralize their effects, such as is seen with chelation therapy.

Option C: Competitive antagonism is a type of receptor antagonism that occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor.

Option D: In uncompetitive inhibition, inhibitors form a complex with an intermediate complex of the substrate and transporter. This inhibits subsequent translocation.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a cough and shortness of breath. He has been working in a shipping factory for 30 years. On x-ray, a mass is seen in the right apical region of the lung. A biopsy sample is taken from the mass. Which of the following tumor markers is likely to be positive in this tumor?
questions.solution:
Calretinin is most likely to be positive in this tumour as the given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare malignant tumour of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure (shipping factory). The lifetime risk of developing mesothelioma in heavily exposed individuals is as high as 7% to 10%. 

It has strong male predilection (3:1). There is a long latent period of 25 to 45 years for the development of asbestos-related mesothelioma.

The image below shows a lung autopsy sample with mesothelioma.

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung becomes ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, grayish pink tumor tissue.

Microscopically, they are of three types: epithelioid (60%), sarcomatoid (20%), and mixed (20%).

Electron microscopy in mesothelioma will show numerous long, slender microvilli and abundant monofilaments but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies.

The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for Calretinin immunostain.

Related Pearl: Differentiation of Mesothelioma from Adenocarcinoma

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the pathogenesis of listeriosis.

choices.text: The bacterium adheres to the microvilli  & disrupts the cell membrane causing diarrhoea.
Listeriolysin  O lyses the cell membrane & allows the Listeriae to move freely from cell-to-cell.
Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host cell actin framework.
Listeria forms elongated protrusions against the host cell membrane called pseudopods; which help in its spread to distant sites.

questions.solution:
Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host cell actin framework.

  • Listeria monocytogenes enters the body through the GIT after ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese or vegetables.
  • It has two cell-surface proteins, internalins A and B, which interact with the epithelial E-cadherin and promote its own phagocytosis into the gut epithelial cells.
  • In the phagolysosome, the low pH activates the bacterium to produce listeriolysin O.
  • This enzyme lyses the membrane of the phagolysosome and allows Listeria to escape into the cytoplasm of the epithelial cell.
  • Here, the organisms proliferate and produce ActA, a listerial protein which induces host cell actin polymerization.
  • This process propels them to the host cell membrane.
  • Pushing against the host cell membrane, they cause the formation of elongated protrusions called filopods.
  • These filopods are ingested by adjacent epithelial cells, macrophages, and hepatocytes, the listeriae are released & the cycle begins again.
  • In this way, Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host actin framework without being exposed to antibodies, complement system, or neutrophils.

questions.text: Sipuleucel-T is the first vaccine approved for the treatment of cancer. This vaccine induces an immune response against which of the following?
questions.solution:
Sipuleucel-T is a cell-based approach to induce an immune response against prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) that is commonly expressed in prostatic cancer. It is approved for use in minimally symptomatic, hormone-refractory, metastatic prostate cancer. 

Sipuleucel-T preparation is done by isolating a patient's peripheral blood cells by leukapheresis and then exposing them to PAP-GM-CSF (which is a human recombinant protein). When these treated cells are infused to a patient, the APCs present in the blood produces antibodies directed against PAP.

Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) is a specific prostate epithelial cell membrane antigen, showing increased expression in prostate cancers, which is also a potential target for monoclonal antibody therapy.

questions.text: Each cycle of β-oxidation produces ___________.
questions.solution:
One cycle of β-oxidation of fatty acids produces 1 FADH2, 1 NADH, and 1 acetyl-CoA.

  • FADH2 is formed in the reaction catalyzed by acyl CoA dehydrogenase.
  • NADH is formed in the reaction catalyzed by β-hydroxy acyl CoA dehydrogenase
  • In each cycle of β-oxidation, the terminal two carbons are cleaved as acetyl CoA starting at carboxyl end.

Thus, the overall reaction of each cycle of β-oxidation can be summarized as follows:

(Cn)acyl CoA + FAD + NAD++ H2O + CoA → (Cn-2)acyl CoA + FADH2 + NADH + Acetyl CoA +H+

questions.text: Identify the condenser in the following image.
questions.solution:
This is a modern compound microscope, and the condenser is located below the stage.

The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light from the illuminator onto the specimen. Microscopes with a stage condenser lens render a sharper image than those with no condenser lens.

The simple microscope was invented first by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the father of microscopy and microbiology. It uses 1 lens for magnification. The compound microscope, introduced by Hans and Zacharias Janssen uses 2 lenses, an objective lens and an eyepiece, to provide better magnification power than the simple microscope.

questions.text: You have been asked to start parenteral iron infusion for a woman at 38 weeks of gestation. What formula would you use to calculate the required dosage?
questions.solution:
The formula for calculating dose of parenteral iron is:

Total dose in mg =  2.4 X (Target Hb - Actual Hb) X Body Wt. + 500 mg

  • 2.4 - conversion factor
  • Target Hb - Hb you want to achieve 
  • Actual Hb- level of current Hb
  • 500 mg - additional amount to replenish the iron stores

Iron sucrose must be diluted only using normal saline at a concentration of 1-2 mg of iron/mL of saline. It is given over 20-30 minutes intravenously.

questions.text: The following effect in the motor neuron is due to:

choices.text: Opening of chloride ion channels through the pre-synaptic neuronal membrane
Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the inside of the neuron
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors
Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron

questions.solution:
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors can cause the effect shown, namely, the generation of IPSP.

In the figure given, there is an increased negativity in the motor neuron following the action potential in the interneuron. So, the synaptic potential is IPSP. This can be caused at the postsynaptic membrane due to Cl- influx, K+ efflux or activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

Other options:

  • Opening of chloride ion channels through the post-synaptic neuronal membrane. 
  • Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the outside of the postsynaptic neuron.
  • Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron causes the generation of an EPSP.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP IPSP
EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)
Results in depolarization of membrane Results in hyperpolarization of membrane
Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane
Neurotransmitters involved – Glutamate, Aspartate Neurotransmitters involved – Glycine, GABA

 

EPSP- Excitatory PostSynaptic Potentials

IPSP- Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potentials

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the following finding. His mother says that he had banged his leg against a chair yesterday. He has had similar episodes in the past but they were never this severe. What lab values will you likely find in this boy?

choices.text: Normal bleeding time, prolonged PT, prolonged aPTT
Normal bleeding time, prolonged PT,  normal aPTT
Prolonged bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT
Normal bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, recurrent hemarthrosis in a male child is suggestive of hemophilia. Normal bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT is seen in hemophilia A and B.

Hemophilia A has decreased factor VIII activity and hemophilia B has decreased factor IX activity.

Note: Prolonged bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT is seen in von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Which of the following mucopolysaccharides does not contain uronic acid?
questions.solution:
Keratan sulfate is a mucopolysaccharide that does not contain uronic acid. It is constituted by repeating disaccharide units of N-acetyl glucosamine and galactose.

Two types of keratan sulfate are seen:

  • Keratan sulfate I - in the cornea
  • Keratan sulfate II - in the cartilage

It is present between the collagen fibrils in the cornea and plays a major role in corneal transparency. Hence, its deficiency can lead to corneal opacity.

questions.text: The skin biopsy from a patient with a vesiculobullous disease is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a sub-epidermal split that is suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

As the antibodies in bullous pemphigoid are directed against BPAg2 and BPAg1 present in the basement membrane zone, intercellular junctions are intact and acantholysis is not seen.

Option A: Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal (suprabasal) acantholytic blisters.

Option B: Pemphigus foliaceus shows intraepidermal (subcorneal) acantholytic blisters.

Option C: In dermatitis herpetiformis, there are papillary tip micro-abscesses. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

questions.text: An orthopedician is performing the following procedure to visualize the anterior cruciate ligament in a patient. Which of the following will be used to sterilise the instrument used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows arthroscopy being performed. Arthroscopes are sterilized using plasma sterilization which utilises hydrogen peroxide. 

In plasma sterilisation, radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapours are passed. This generates plasma which contains free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. Plasma denatures all organisms and is used sterilize arthroscopes and ureteroscopes. Sterilization control is monitored by Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus. 

Option A: Ethylene oxide has both microbicidal and sporicidal activity. It is used for sterilisation heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, suture materials etc. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillius atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilus.

Option B: Gamma rays cause breakage of DNA. It destroys spores and vegetative cells, but is not effective against viruses. It is referred to as cold sterilisation and is used in commercial plants to sterilize plastics, syringes, swabs. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillus pumilius. 

Option D: Ultraviolet rays are used to sterilise biosafety cabinets, entryways, operation theatres and laboratories.

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is ________
questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme. This most commonly occurs following a herpes simplex virus infection.

The common triggers are:

  • Herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs- sulfonamides, rifampicin, penicillins, hydantoin derivatives
  • Miscellaneous- lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), sarcoidosis, polyarteritis nodosa

Erythema multiforme is best regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity.

It presents clinically with a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic acral iris or ‘target lesions’.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  1. Central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  2. Middle paler zone of edema
  3. Outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge

Lesions may involve the palms and the trunk. Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions

The image below shows target lesions.

questions.text: A 21-year-old homeless pregnant woman gives birth to a premature infant with a palmoplantar bullous eruption. The RPR titer of the cord blood is elevated. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Elevated RPR titer of the cord blood is indicative of congenital syphilis in the infant. Seventh nerve palsy is not a feature of congenital syphilis. It is associated with 8th nerve deafness, along with tinnitus and vertigo. It is a part of Hutchinson's triad which includes the following:      

  1. Interstitial keratitis
  2. Eighth nerve deafness
  3. Hutchinson's teeth

One of the features of congenital syphilis is periostitis of the skull which results in parrot's nodes or hot-cross bun appearance.

Most newborns with congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth. However, a vesiculobullous rash called syphilitic pemphigus may be present at delivery. After 2 weeks, a maculopapular rash is more common. Clinical signs usually appear between weeks 3 to 8 of life, usually within 3 months.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.solution:
Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable.

The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method.

Age Head circumference
At birth 33 to 35cm
3 m 40 cm
6 m 43 cm
1 year 46 cm
2 years 48 cm
3 years 49 cm
4 years 50 cm
12 years 52 cm (adult size)
  • Head circumference increases by the following:
    • 2 cm/month in first 3 months
    • 1 cm/month in next 3 months
    • 0.5 cm/month in next 6 months

Head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm at birth.

  • At birth: Head circumference > Chest circumference
  • At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference
  • After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference

Interesting fact!

A boy's height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height and a girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height.

To roughly predict adult height, use the formula:

  • Adult height = height at 2.5 years for boys (or 2 years for girls) X 2

According to WHO growth charts, the height-for-age for most of the children lies between 70-90 cm during these periods. The double of it, i.e. 140-180 cm is the average height that most of us achieve as adults.

questions.text: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of _____.
questions.solution:
Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of imipenem.

Imipenem is rapidly hydrolysed by the enzyme renal dehydropeptidase present. It is administered with cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase to inhibit the breakdown and prolong the action of imipenem.

Other options:

Option B- Meropenem is not hydrolyzed by renal dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin administration is not necessary with meropenem.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case?
questions.solution:
The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells. 

Korner’s septum separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells.

Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not identified. Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed.

Below is an image showing Korner's septum -

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with superior mesenteric artery occlusion underwent extensive bowel resection. Following surgery, he developed short bowel syndrome and has been on parenteral nutrition. Which of the following drugs would be beneficial for his condition?
questions.solution:
Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analog and is approved for the treatment of short bowel syndrome.

GLP-2 binds to enteric neurons and endocrine cells, stimulating the release of a number of hormones such as insulin-like growth factor. This stimulates mucosal epithelial growth and enhances fluid absorption.

GLP-1 analogs:

  • Exenatide 
  • Liraglutide 
  • Albiglutide 
  • Dulaglutide
  • Lixisenatide 
  • Semaglutide

Note: GLP-1 analogs are used for the treatment of Type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought with complaints of sensitivity to light and profuse lacrimation. On inspection, the given finding is seen on her upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Spring catarrh or vernal keratoconjunctivitis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

It is a bilateral, seasonally recurrent, chronic conjunctivitis due to type I hypersensitivity allergic reaction to an external antigen. The antigen reacts with IgE, this stimulates mast cell degranulation leading to the release of histamine and other mediators of the allergic response.

Spring catarrh is one of the several forms of allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about malignant otitis externa?

choices.text: It is due to pseudomonas infection
Technetium 99 bone scan is used for follow up
Facial nerve is the most common affected nerve

questions.solution:
Technetium 99 bone scan remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to follow up response to treatment. It is particularly useful when the clinical suspicion for malignant otitis externa is high but the CT scan is negative.

Features of malignant otitis externa:

  • Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal.
  • Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.
  • Mitotic figures will be normal since it is an infective and not a malignant condition.
  • Gallium-67 is more useful in the follow-up of the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of RAS oncogene?
questions.solution:
The 3 ras genes in humans (H-RAS, K-RAS, and N-RAS) are the most common oncogenes in human cancer.

Ras oncogenes code for a family of proteins called GTP-binding (G) proteins, which are involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction).

When ras is 'switched on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately turn on genes involved in cell growth, differentiation, and survival.

Mutations in ras genes can lead to the production of permanently activated ras proteins. As a result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive ras signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.

questions.text: Identify the following vector which transmits murine typhus.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a rat flea-Xenopsylla cheopis. It transmits murine typhus.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: The method shown in the image below is called chasing the dragon. Which drug is taken through this route?
questions.solution:
Chasing the dragon is a method used to take heroin.

In this, users inhale a thick, white pyrolysate that is generated by heating heroin base on aluminum foil using a hand-held flame. This means of administration produces heroin concentrations similar to those observed following IV administration.

Other methods used to take drugs are:

  • Mainlining - Intravenous injection
  • Insufflation - Snorting
  • Skin popping - Subcutaneous injection

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman suffering from Huntington's chorea is on haloperidol. Which of the following adverse drug effects is best attributed to the supersensitivity of dopamine receptors?

choices.text: Muscle rigidity, labile blood pressure, hyperreflexia, hyperthermia, tachycardia, tremors
Lip smacking, facial dyskinesia, protrusion and rolling of the tongue, involuntary movements of the extremities
Facial grimacing, involuntary upward eye movement, laryngeal spasm and arching of the trunk forward
Stooped posture, rigidity, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, and pill rolling tremors

questions.solution:
Lip-smacking, facial dyskinesia, protrusion and rolling of the tongue, and involuntary movements of the extremities are characteristic of tardive dyskinesia. This is caused by supersensitivity of dopamine receptors. 

It occurs as a consequence of chronic postsynaptic D2 receptor blockade by antipsychotics, which results in upregulation and supersensitivity of postsynaptic dopamine receptors.

Tardive dyskinesia is usually seen in patients treated with typical antipsychotics (first generation) for more than a year. This may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation. Treatment is with valbenazine, deutetrabenazine (VMAT2 inhibitors).

questions.text: The nucleus indicated by the arrow shown in the longitudinal section of the nerve fibers in the image belongs to ______
questions.solution:
The image shows the nucleus of Schwann cells.

Nerve fibers (axons) in the peripheral nervous system may be myelinated or unmyelinated. The myelin sheath surrounding the myelinated nerve fibers is provided by the Schwann cells. The cytoplasm and the nucleus of the Schwann cells are pushed to the periphery. Since each axon is surrounded by myelin sheaths provided by several axons, on H&E staining, several nuclei of these Schwann cells appear as basophilic structures on either side of the axon along its length.

Other options:

  • In the question, it is already mentioned that the given section is of the nerve fiber. However, in case it is not mentioned, on H&E stain the smooth muscle cells appear spindle-shaped, with a centrally placed, elongated nucleus.
  • The fibroblasts may be seen in the perineurium or endoneurium surrounding the bundles of nerve fibers. They are elongated and stain denser than the nuclei of Schwann cells.
  • The dorsal root ganglion consists of cell bodies of the neurons, with satellite cells.

questions.text: Ubiquitin is a key molecule in protein degradation. Ubiquitinated proteins are degraded by ______
questions.solution:
Ubiquitinated proteins are degraded by proteasomes.

Abnormal proteins and aged normal proteins are conjugated to the polypeptide ubiquitin which marks them for degradation (ubiquitination). The ubiquitinated proteins are degraded by proteasomes. 

Clinical importance: Proteasome inhibitor - bortezomib is used in multiple myeloma and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants?

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.solution:
The curare group of drugs includes non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents that act by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors.

This leads to a decrease in the effect of acetylcholine and thus, neuronal transmission to the muscle does not occur.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of an unconscious man showed pH- 6.9, HCO3- 13 mEq/L, paCO2- 68 mmHg. The acid-base status of this patient is best described as:

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation

questions.solution:
According to the ABG analysis provided, the patient has a mixed acid-base disorder with simultaneous respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 6.9 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 13 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 68 mmHg indicating co-existing respiratory acidosis. The direction of pCO2 change is the same as that of pH change suggesting that this is a mixed acid-base disorder.

Step 4: The expected compensatory change in pCO2 in the metabolic acidosis calculated using Winter's formula would be:

pCO2 = [1.5xHCO3-] + 8 ± 2 = 26 - 30 mmHg

The actual pCO2 measure is very high (68 mmHg) compared to the estimated range of 26 - 30 mmHg indicating the presence of simultaneous metabolic and respiratory acidosis.

Note- If this was a case of uncompensated acidosis, either the bicarbonate or the pCO2 values would have been within the normal limits. 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: What is the causative organism of Trench fever?
questions.solution:
Trench fever, more commonly known as five-day fever is caused by Bartonella quintana. It is transmitted by the human body louse.

During the First World War, over a million cases of trench fever occurred among soldiers fighting in the trenches in Europe. This is probably where this disease got its name from.

Trench fever was thought to have vanished with the World Wars. Recently, some cases have been identified in homeless persons living in unsanitary conditions in the USA.

questions.text: An elderly woman with hypothyroidism presents to the ER with decreased consciousness, hypothermia, sinus bradycardia, and hypotension. Her family members reveal that she has not been taking her thyroid medications recently. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels and reduced T3 and T4 levels. All of the following can be used in the treatment except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of myxedema coma. Hypotonic IV fluids are avoided in the course of treatment of this condition. However, hypertonic saline is used.

Hypotonic fluids may exacerbate water retention and dilutional hyponatremia secondary to impaired renal perfusion and inappropriate vasopressin.

Treatment of myxedema coma includes:

  • Levothyroxine (T4) can be administered as a single IV bolus of 500 μg. Although further doses are strictly not required, it is continued at 50-100 μg/day.
  • An alternative mode of treatment is the IV administration of liothyronine (T3) or via NG tubes with doses ranging from 10-25 μg every 8-12 hours in case T4 to T3 conversion in myxedema is impaired.
  • Parenteral hydrocortisone should be administered to treat a condition of impaired adrenal reserve in profound hypothyroidism.
  • Hypertonic saline or IV glucose may be recommended for treatment.
  • External warming is indicated only if the temperature is less than 30oC.

questions.text: At what concentration does the administration of an inhaled general anesthetic prevent movement in response to noxious stimuli in 50% of the population?
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the inhaled anesthetic concentration required to prevent movement in response to noxious stimuli in 50% of patients.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients.
