MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: Which group does the antianxiety drug buspirone belong to?
questions.solution:
The antianxiety drug buspirone is a partial agonist of 5-HT1A receptors. The most important locations of the 5-HT1A receptor are raphe nuclei of brainstem and hippocampus. 

It mimics the antianxiety properties of benzodiazepines but does not interact with GABAA receptors or display the sedative and anticonvulsant properties of benzodiazepines. Buspirone is primarily used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder.

5-HT1A partial agonists are:

  • Buspirone
  • Gepirone
  • Ipsapirone

questions.text: A patient presented with vaginal bleeding following 6 weeks of amenorrhoea. Her UPT was positive. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of first-trimester abortion which is most commonly caused by chromosomal abnormalities.

Autosomal trisomies are the most common (50%) genetic abnormality overall. Of these, the most common trisomy involved in abortions is trisomy 16. Turner syndrome (monosomy X) is the single most common chromosomal abnormality in miscarriages.

Causes of spontaneous abortion are:

  • Genetic - 
    • Numerical chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosomal rearrangements
    • Mendelian etiology
  • Endocrine -
    • Luteal phase defects
    • Thyroid abnormalities
    • Diabetes mellitus
  • Anatomical - 
    • Cervical incompetence
    • Congenital uterine malformations
    • Uterine fibroid
    • Uterine synechiae
  • Infectious (TORCH infections)
  • Immunological -
    • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
    • Autoimmunity
  • Maternal illness - 
    • Cyanotic heart diseases
    • Hemoglobinopathies
  • Environmental -
    • Radiation exposure
    • Alcohol
    • Cigarette smoking

questions.text: Which among the following bones is most useful for sex determination?
questions.solution:
The femur is the most useful long bone for sex determination, due to its length and massiveness.

The accuracy of sex determination from bones depends greatly on the age of the subject, the degree of fragmentation, and biological variability. Obvious differences in bones between genders do not become apparent until after puberty. The accuracy of sex determination also depends on whether the total skeleton is available for examination.  

All long bones have a considerable overlap of characteristics between male and female bones. However, there is a significant difference between male and female femurs. For example, the maximum oblique length in the male femur is 459mm but the female femur is only 426mm. 

Pearson and Bell's criteria for sexing of the femur are:

Criteria Male Male or Female Female

Vertical diameter of the femoral head

  >45.5 43.5-41.5 <41.5

Popliteal length

 >145 114-132 <106

Bicondylar width

 >78 74-76 <72

Oblique trochanteric length

 >450 405-430 <390

 

Among these, the most useful criterion is that of the vertical diameter of femoral head.

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with cervical incompetence?

choices.text: Repeated third trimester painless cervical dilatation
Bleeding per vaginum in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is characterized by repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. Escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of products of conception can also be seen.

Risk factors for cervical incompetence:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Acquired -
    • Dilatation and currettage 
    • Dilatation and evacuation
    • Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix
    • Amputation of cervix 
  • Multiple gestations
  • Prior preterm birth

questions.text: A patient with a family history of nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with nasal discharge and a painless lump in the upper neck. On posterior rhinoscopy, where will you most commonly expect to find a mass originating from?
questions.solution: The most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.

questions.text: All of the following can lead to an increase in temperature of the body in the first two hours following death except:
questions.solution:
Cholera, septicemia, and sunstroke lead to an increase in body temperature in the first two hours following death.

Postmortem caloricity is the condition in which the temperature of the body remains raised for about the first two hours after death.

It occurs:

  • When the regulation of body temperature has been severely disturbed before death as in sunstroke, pontine hemorrhage
  • Increased heat production in muscles due to convulsions as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning
  • When there has been increased bacterial activity as in septicemia, cholera

questions.text: Which of the following is not an embryologic structure that contributes to the formation of the face?
questions.solution:
Zygomatic prominence is not an embryological structure that contributes to the formation of the face. 

The face is derived from the following structures around the stomatodeum (primitive mouth):

  • Mandibular prominences and maxillary prominences of the first arch 
  • Frontonasal prominence formed by the proliferation of mesenchyme ventral to the brain vesicles. It also gives rise to medial and lateral nasal prominences. 
Structures contributing to the development of face
Prominence Structure formed
Frontonasal Forehead, bridge of the nose, also forms the medial and lateral nasal prominences
Medial nasal Philtrum of the upper lip, the crest of the nose, and the tip of the nose
Lateral nasal Alae of nose
Maxillary Upper part of cheeks, the lateral portion of the upper lip
Mandibular Lower part of cheeks, chin, lower lip

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about immunotherapy of cancer?

choices.text: Intralesional BCG has been used successfully in the treatment of basal cell carcinoma
Interferons are used in the treatment of  squamous cell carcinomas
Dinitrochlorobenzene is used in the treatment of leukemia
Lymphokine activated killer (LAK) cells are used in the treatment of renal cell carcinomas

questions.solution:
There are different approaches in the immunotherapy of cancer which include passive, active and adoptive immunotherapy.

Lymphokine activated killer (LAK) cells obtained by treatment of natural killer cells with interleukin-2 are used in adoptive immunotherapy in the treatment of renal cell carcinomas.

Passive immunotherapy was the earliest method of cancer immunotherapy which involved administration of the antisera, prepared by immunizing animals with tumor biopsy specimen. This method was later abandoned.

Active immunotherapy:

  • Dinitrochlorobenzene for treatment of squamous and basal cell carcinomas
  • Interferons which are used in the treatment of leukaemia
  • Intralesional BCG in malignant melanoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: Which of the following will be the most important prognostic indicator in patients with stage 1 melanoma?
questions.solution:
The best prognostic factor in primary stage 1 melanoma (T1N0) is the tumor thickness or depth of the melanoma. 

The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index for melanoma in general. But in Stage 1 melanoma, as there is no lymph node involvement, the depth of the melanoma is the best prognostic factor.

 Other major prognostic factors, in order of impact on survival, include:

  • Presence of lymph node metastases
  • Ulceration
  • Age
  • Anatomic location of the primary tumor 
  • Gender

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. His moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for him?
questions.solution:
The patient has rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid-cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year

Episodes either have a partial or full remission for at least 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

Other options:

Option A: Lamotrigine has been found to have limited uses in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. It can prolong the time between depression and mania.

Option C: Carbamazepine takes 2-3 weeks for the onset of action and is used in patients not responding to Lithium in Acute Mania.

Option D: Lithium takes 5-7 days to achieve a level of equilibrium, moreover it is effective in Bipolar I disorder and is less efficacious than Divalproex in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder.

 

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add-on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: A patient with heart failure in the ICU is being administered fluids. Which is the method of non-invasive cardiac monitoring used to titrate the treatment for this patient on a regular basis?
questions.solution:
Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the noninvasive form of cardiac monitoring that can be used in this patient.   

Option C: Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)  is a minimally invasive procedure and could be associated with serious complications like oesophagal rupture and mediastinitis in the presence of oesophagal injury or disease. In the absence of oesophagal disease, the risk is low.

questions.text: Which of the following is not  a part of the 4 A's of Bleuler ?
questions.solution:
Avolition is not a part of the 4 A's of Bleuler .

The term schizophrenia was introduced by Eugen Bleuler. He described the primary symptoms of schizophrenia, known as the 4 A's of Bleuler.

This includes:

  • Autism- social withdrawal with excessive irrational fantasy thinking.
  • Ambivalence- marked inability to take a decision.
  • Association disturbances- loosening of association refers to changing the topic without identifiable links between the subjects.
  • Affect problems- flattening of affect or inappropriate affect.

questions.text: A female patient was infused with a solution which leads to rapid lysis of the RBCs. Which solution was most likely infused?
questions.solution:
Urea is a highly permeable solute, 300mMol/L urea solution behaves as a hypotonic solution.

Urea diffuses to the inside of RBC's via UTB channels very rapidly, while the rest of the solutes in the ECF cannot enter the cell. So the ECF now becomes hypotonic. So, fluid enters the RBC and causes their lysis.

Other Options :

  • Option A : The solution is iso-osmotic. (150mmol of NaCl contains 150mmol of Na+ and 150mmol of Cl- ions making the total osmolality 300 mOsm/L.This is equivalent to 0.9% NaCl which is isotonic.)
  • Option B and C: The solutions are hyper-osmotic. This will lead to shrinking of the RBCs.

Note : 

  • If a cell is placed into a hypotonic solution that has a lower concentration of impermeant solutes (<282 mOsm/L), water will diffuse into the cell, causing it to swell. 
  • If a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution having a higher concentration of impermeant solutes, water will flow out of the cell leading to cell shrinkage.

questions.text: A patient reports sleep deprivation, and low mood, following his daughter's diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia one month ago. He also admits to excessive drinking and reckless driving that started around the same time. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing the above symptoms following his daughter's recent diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (stressor). It is a case of adjustment disorder. 

Adjustment disorders are maladaptive reactions to an identifiable psychosocial stressor like marital problems, financial instability, and medical illness. Up to 3 months may elapse between a stressor and the development of symptoms. The disorder can occur at any age, and its symptoms vary considerably, with depressive, anxious, and mixed features most common in adults. Physical symptoms, which are most common in children and the elderly, can occur in any age group.

Manifestations may also include assaultive behavior and reckless driving, excessive drinking, defaulting on legal responsibilities, withdrawal, vegetative signs, insomnia, and suicidal behavior.

Treatment:

  • Remove or reduce the stressor
  • Brief psychotherapy to improve coping skills
  • Pharmacotherapy- Anxiolytic or antidepressant medications if psychotherapy is not effective

Note: Major depressive disorder requires the presence of at least five of the following features for the diagnosis -

Depressed mood most of the day; markedly diminished interest in activities most of the day; diminished ability to think or concentrate; psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day; changes in appetite or weight; feelings of guilt; loss of energy; insomnia or hypersomnia; recurring thoughts of death or suicide. The absence of these other features with the presence of a clear stressor, makes the diagnosis of adjustment disorder more accurate.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding left-sided diverticulitis?

choices.text: It is often an incidental finding during surgery
Appendicitis is an important differential diagnosis
Left sided diverticulitis is more common than right
The anatomical location is given by the Hinchey classification

questions.solution:
In the general population, left-sided diverticulitis is more common. The sigmoid colon (left colon) involvement is more common than the right colon involvement.  

Diverticulitis is the inflammation and infection of the diverticulum. It most commonly presents with

  • left lower abdominal pain (often termed as left-sided appendicitis)
  • fever
  • a change in bowel habits
  • anorexia, nausea
  • urinary urgency if there is an associated inflammation of the bladder etc.

Right-sided diverticulitis occurs more often in younger patients of Asian descent than in other populations and presents with pain in the right lower quadrant. Patients presenting with these symptoms are often thought to have acute appendicitis, and often the diagnosis of right-sided diverticulitis is subsequently made in the operating room.

The Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity of the diverticular disease, complicated by perforation.

Hinchey classification:

Stage 1

Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: A patient having chronic otitis media with perforation of pars tensa is scheduled for myringoplasty to restore hearing. Which of the following is true regarding the techniques used here?

choices.text: In underlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In underlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus
In overlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In overlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus

questions.solution:
In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to malleus in both techniques.

Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft with lamina propria of tympanic membrane remnants and fibrous annulus.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with a sore throat for 3 days. Which of the following medium is used to culture the throat swab?
questions.solution:
Blood agar is the preferred culture media as it is used for the culture and isolation of Streptococcus pyogenes which is the most common cause of sore throat.

The selective medium for Streptococcus pyogenes is Crystal violet blood agar and the transport media for this organism is Pikes medium.

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

PEMBA(polymyxin in egg yolk mannitol bromothymol blue agar

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A patient being treated with ampicillin presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. C. difficile infection is suspected. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin B, indicated to reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI).

Actoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin A but it is not approved because of lack of efficacy. 

Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha antibody used in rheumatoid arthritis and various other conditions.

questions.text: The following finding was noted on the cardiac tissue specimen of an 82-year-old man. Which of the following is false about the given finding?

choices.text: It is a tell-tale sign of free radical injury
It is injurious to the cell and its function
It is derived through lipid peroxidation
It can also be seen in liver of aging patients

questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows yellow-brown lipochrome or lipofuscin pigment. It is not injurious to the cell or its functions.

Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment derived from the peroxidation of lipids of subcellular membranes. It is an indicator of free radical injury to the cells.

It is an insoluble, brownish yellow, granular intracellular material that is seen in the liver, brain, and heart due to normal aging. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.

It can also be seen in patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a partial agonist at beta-2 receptors?
questions.solution:
Salmeterol is a partial agonist at beta-2 receptors. 

Formoterol is a complete agonist at beta-2 receptors.

questions.text: Vasopressin acting on its V2 receptor uses _____ as its second messenger.
questions.solution:
Vasopressin acts on the V2 receptor using cAMP as its second messenger.

Vasopressin acts on GPCR using different second messengers to accomplish its various actions as follows:

  • V1 receptor - vasoconstriction using phospholipase C as its second messenger
  • V2 receptor - reabsorption of water through aquaporin 2, using cAMP as its second messenger

Vasopressin has a maximum effect on the collecting ducts. It acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required. 

Related Pearl: Summary of Stimuli affecting Vasopressin Secretion

Increased vasopressin secretion

Decreased vasopressin secretion

Increased effective osmotic pressure of the plasma

Decreased ECF volume

Pain, emotions, stress, exercise

Nausea and vomiting

Standing

Angiotensin II

Clofibrate, carbamazepine

Decreased effective osmotic pressure of the plasma

Increased ECF volume

Alcohol

questions.text: The histological feature shown below is likely to be seen in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
The histological feature depicted above is a psammoma body, which is least likely to be found in "Cowdens Syndrome". 

Psammoma bodies are calcified deposits representing clumps of sloughed cells found in Papillary Thyroid Cancers, Meningiomas and Mesotheliomas. 

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are associated with tumour syndromes such as Gardners syndrome and very rarely Cowdens. Cowdens syndrome is more frequently associated with follicular thyroid carcinoma. 

Related Pearl: Psammoma Bodies

Psammoma bodies are visible in the following:

  • Meningioma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma Ovary
  • Papillary carcinoma thyroid.
  • Papillary type of renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 1.9 Kg neonate delivered at 32 weeks has abdominal distention and hematochezia on the 11th day of life. The abdomen x-ray is as shown below. What is the stage of disease according to Modified Bell's Staging Criteria?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray image shows gas accumulation in the submucosa of the bowel wall- pneumatosis intestinalis, a pathognomonic finding of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), seen in stage IIA, according to the Modified Bell Staging Criteria.

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria:

Stage   Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs Treatment
IA Suspected NEC Mild abdominal distention, emesis, guaiac-positive stool Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus NPO, Antibiotic for 3 days 
IB   IA + Bright red blood from the rectum Same as IA Same as IA Same as IA
IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sounds Same as IA  Pneumatosis intestinalis, ileus NPO, Antibiotics for 7-10 days 
IIB Moderately ill  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness IA+ Metabolic acidosis and thrombocytopenia   IIA + portal venous gas, with or without ascites NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days 
IIIA Severely ill, bowel intact  IIB + peritonitis with marked tenderness, and abdominal distension  IIB+ hypotension, bradycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia  IIB + definite ascitis  NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days, fluid resuscitation +/- inotropes, ventilator, paracentesis
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A Same as IIIA   IIB +pneumoperitoneum Same as III A, surgery 

Stage I - Suspected NEC
Stage II - Proven NEC
Stage III - Advanced NEC

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a history of fever and chest pain for the last 7 days. A chest X-ray was done. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and X-ray is suggestive of loculated pleural effusion.

The chest X-ray shows obliteration of right costophrenic angle with a wide pleural-based dome-shaped opacity projecting into the lung. It tracks along the costphrenic angle and lateral chest wall.

A pleural lesion can be differentiated from a parenchymal lesion by the angle it makes with the chest wall. Pleural lesions makes an obtuse angle with the chest wall whereas a parenchymal lesions makes an acute angle with the chest wall.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen.

An infarct is a region of ischaemic necrosis resulting from the obstruction of blood flow, typically due to occlusion of the arterial supply or venous drainage. The most common cause of solid organ infarts is thromboembolism.

The pattern of ischemic necrosis seen in solid organ infarction is coagulative necrosis. However, CNS infarctions are an exception. They cause liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: A woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is seen when the concentration of deoxygenated or reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥0.5 gm%.

Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation <85%. In dark-skinned individuals, it may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.text: Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining pattern may reflect antibodies to all the following except:
questions.solution:
Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining does not reflect antibodies to RNA. The nucleolar pattern of staining represents antibodies to RNA.

 Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are directed against antibodies to:

  • DNA
  • Histones
  • Nonhistone proteins bound to RNA
  • Nucleolar antigens

The most widely used method for detecting ANAs is indirect immunofluorescence. The pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: A non-sterile hypopyon is seen in______.
questions.solution:
Fungal keratitis can cause non-sterile hypopyon.

Unlike bacterial ulcer, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation.

Aspergillus spp. are the most common cause.

Hypopyon in a fungal ulcer is fixed, non-sterile and contains fungal filaments.

questions.solution:
Cortisol is a steroid hormone and acts on intracellular (cytoplasmic) receptor.

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding multifetal pregnancies?

choices.text: Number of embryos implanted affects the risk of twinning
Isograft is done between monozygotic twins
Twins of opposite sex are usually dizygotic
Same sex twins having same blood group are always monozygotic

questions.solution:
Same sex twins of the same blood group are not always monozygotic but can also be dizygotic twins as well. The genetic relationship between dizygotic twins is the same as any siblings.

Option A: More the number of embryos transferred in IVF, more is the risk of twinning. Hence, single embryo transfer is being recommended by the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (2017) to prevent twin gestation.

Option B: Isograft is done between monozygotic twins as they have HLA homology.

Option C: Twins of the opposite sex are usually dizygotic. Rarely, somatic mutations or chromosomal aberrations can change the sex of 1 or both of the monozygotic twins.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:

  • Circummarginate placenta -  In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. 
  • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are:
    • Preterm delivery
    • Abortions
    • IUGR
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Retained placenta and membranes

Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins.

Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray image depicts Chilaiditi sign, characterized by the anterior interposition of the colon between the liver and the right hemidiaphragm, which can mimic air under the diaphragm, leading to pseudo-pneumoperitoneum.

Chilaiditi sign is typically an incidental finding on imaging and is most often asymptomatic. However, when associated with symptoms such as abdominal pain and distension, it is referred to as Chilaiditi syndrome. 

An erect X-ray showing this sign may mislead clinicians into suspecting pneumoperitoneum, prompting unnecessary urgent surgical intervention, which is not required. To differentiate Chilaiditi syndrome from true pneumoperitoneum, a contrast-enhanced CT or a left lateral decubitus radiograph can be performed. In the left lateral decubitus view, distended colonic loops with haustral markings will be visible, showing that the air is within the bowel and not in the peritoneal cavity. 

Other conditions with the Chilaiditi sign are curvilinear pulmonary collapse, distended viscus, omental fat, and apposition of gas-distended bowel loops mimicking the double-wall sign.

Below is the chest X-ray and CT showing the presence of herniated bowel loops under the diaphragm.

Other options:

Option A: The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows free intraperitoneal gas which is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. The presence of free intra-abdominal gas almost always indicates perforation of a hollow viscus. Free intraperitoneal gas is also detectable under the hemidiaphragm on an erect chest X-ray as given below. 

Option B: The existence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum is referred to as pneumomediastinum. Gas may originate from the peritoneal cavity, lungs, trachea, central bronchi, oesophagus, or peritoneal cavity and travel to the neck or abdomen via the mediastinum.  Spinnaker sign (also called angel wing sign) is a radiographic sign seen in neonates with pneumomediastinum. The pressure from the collected gas displaces the two lobes of the thymic tissue upward and laterally from its normal position. This results in large, wedge-shaped opacities on radiograph resembling the spinnaker headsails of a boat.  Other signs of pneumomediastinum are the V sign of Naclerio and continuous diaphragm sign. 

Below is a chest X-ray showing spinnaker sign and CT showing the presence of pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with chronic abdominal discomfort. Imaging reveals a solitary well-encapsulated hepatic mass with a central fibrous scar and stellate calcification. Further investigations reveal elevated neurotensin levels and negative hepatitis B serology. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Histology reveals oncocytic hepatocytes separated by collagen bundles
It is associated with a relatively good prognosis
Majority of these tumors are resectable
It is associated with liver cirrhosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fibrolamellar carcinoma. It is usually not associated with liver cirrhosis.

Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive and rare variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It usually occurs < 35 years of age. There is no gender predilection and no identifiable predisposing conditions. It has a good prognosis compared to the classical HCC. Majority (50-75%) of these tumors are resectable.

It usually presents as a single large, hard scirrhous tumor with fibrous bands coursing through it. Microscopically, it is composed of oncocytes growing in nests or cords separated by parallel lamellae of dense collagen bundles.

The histological section of fibrolamellar carcinoma is given below. It shows malignant-appearing, oncocytic hepatocytes separated by dense bundles of collagen.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and fibrolamellar carcinoma

questions.text: A patient with psychosis presents in the Ophthalmology OPD with diminished vision. His examination reveals the following picture. Which of the following drugs could have caused this?
questions.solution:
The picture shows retinitis pigmentosa (retinal hyperpigmentation, waxy disc pallor, and arteriolar attenuation seen on fundus examination). The drug is thioridazine.

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

 

Typical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Chlorpromazine Corneal & lenticular deposits, vortex keratopathy, obstructive jaundice
Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation

 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects

Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract
Ziprasidone QT prolongation

Aripiprazole Hypoprolactinemia

questions.text: The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is known as the ________.
questions.solution:
The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that infection occurs among susceptible persons following known contact with an infectious person within incubation period

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)

  • Primary cases are usually excluded from the numerator and denominator.
  • Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the given options.

Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Prior ectopic pregnancy
  • Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy
  • Infertility
  • Artificial reproductive therapy
  • Endometriosis
  • Smoking
  • Maternal age >40 years
  • Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills

questions.text: In a normal ECG obtained from a patient, a biphasic P wave may be seen in which of the following lead(s)?
questions.solution:
In a normal ECG, a biphasic P wave is seen in lead V1 only.

Lead V1 is a chest lead. So, it records potentials in the horizontal plane. The P wave in lead V1 consists of:

  • Positive component reflecting right atrial depolarization (due to anteriorly oriented vector)
  • Negative component reflecting left atrial depolarization (due to posteriorly oriented vector)

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is alirocumab approved for use?

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age

questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are a new class of lipid-lowering medications that are administered as monthly or bimonthly subcutaneous injections. PCSK9 is a binding protein that is expressed in hepatocytes and on secretion, binds to the LDL receptors, and promotes their degradation. By blocking PCSK9, these drugs increase the availability of LDL receptors leading to better removal of LDL cholesterol from circulation. Another approved PCSK-9 inhibitor is evolocumab.

Other options: 

Option B: Fremanezumab and galcanezumab are anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies approved by the FDA in 2018 for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

Option C: Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor is FDA approved for cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age. It facilitates the opening of chloride channels.

Option D: Plecanatide is FDA-approved for the treatment of chronic idiopathic constipation. It activates guanylate cyclase-C on endothelial cells in the GI tract and thus draws water into the lumen, leading to stool softening.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Typhoid carriers are not at risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma. 

Cholangiocarcinoma is the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after hepatocellular carcinoma. It is a malignancy of the biliary tree, arising from bile ducts within and outside of the liver.

The risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma include the following:

  • Infestation by liver flukes (particularly Opisthorchis and Clonorchis )
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis, and other chronic inflammatory diseases of the large bile ducts
  • Chronic hepatitis B and C infections
  • Cirrhosis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Diabetes mellitus, obesity, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
  • Alcohol and tobacco
  • Precursor lesions -
    • Biliary intraepithelial neoplasias
    • Mucinous cystic neoplasms
    • Intraductal papillary biliary neoplasia

questions.text: In the assessment of a patient’s airway, which of the following cannot be used?
questions.solution:
BURP is not a method of assessment of airway.

BURP is a technique of external laryngeal manipulation of the airway during intubation for better visualization of the larynx. This involves Backward, Upward, Rightward Pressure on thyroid cartilage.

Various methods of airway assessments are

Mallampati classification: correlates tongue size to pharyngeal size.

Cormack and Lehane grading is based on laryngoscopy view

Wilson’s scoring is based on 5 factors: weight, upper spine mobility, jaw movement, receding mandible, and buck teeth.

BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers do you expect to be elevated in a patient suffering from unstable angina?
questions.solution:
No cardiac biomarkers are elevated in unstable angina (UA).

UA is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no elevation of biomarkers. If cardiac biomarkers are elevated in these patients, then the diagnosis of MI is considered.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) includes:

  • Unstable angina(UA)
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI)
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

questions.text: A lady comes with a reddish firm nodule on her chest which hasn't grown in size. Its histolopathological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with reddish firm nodule on her chest and histology showing multiple dilated vascular structures with a single layer of epithelial cells is suggestive of a hemangioma.

Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of hemangioma are capillary hemangioma (most common), juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma, cavernous hemangioma and pyogenic hemangioma.

Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to a large hemangioma over the eyelid).

Treatment options include:

  • Beta-blockers - oral propranolol
  • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser

The given image shows a flat to elevated, irregular, pinkish-red mass over the skin of the abdomen suggestive of a strawberry hemangioma.

The given image shows a capillary hemangioma in a child

questions.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is needed in therapy with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Coagulation profile monitoring is needed for lepirudin.

Lepirudin is a direct irreversible thrombin inhibitor and its most adverse reaction is bleeding. The risk of bleeding can be reduced by implementing an appropriate monitoring and dose adjustment strategy. Thus, coagulation profile monitoring is required for lepirudin.

However, enoxaparin, fondaparinux, and dabigatran do not bind to endothelium or many plasma proteins and thus, the response to these drugs at the usual doses is consistent from patient to patient. Hence, monitoring is not required.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.solution:
There is an increase in the metabolism of glycogen in the vaginal epithelium during normal pregnancy.

The changes in the vagina during pregnancy include:

  • Increased vascularity and hyperemia resulting in a violet/purplish color characteristic of Chadwick's sign
  • Vaginal epithelium undergoes marked proliferation (option D) with the extension of the squamocolumnar junction downwards
  • Vaginal pH decreases and becomes more acidic (option C) and varies from 3.5-6.0.
  • Increase in the number of Lactobacillus acidophilus (option A). It metabolizes the glycogen stores and causes an increased production of lactic acid. Therefore, the pH becomes acidic.
  • Increased volume of cervical secretion during pregnancy results in the production of thick white vaginal discharge.

questions.text: A mother noticed yellowish discoloration of her term newborn within the first 6 hours of life. On examination, jaundice extended up to the lower abdomen and thighs. Which of the following drugs can be administered along with phototherapy?
questions.solution:
Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for pathological jaundice in neonates.

It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy.

Tolazoline is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that produces systemic and pulmonary vasodilatation, which is used to correct pulmonary artery vasospasm when it causes severe right-left shunting soon after birth.

Tromethamine is an organic buffer used in the management of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody is approved for use in HIV-1?
questions.solution:
Ibalizumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for use in the treatment of resistant HIV-1 infections. 

Ibalizumab blocks HIV-1 from infecting CD4+ T cells by binding to domain 2 of CD4 cells. It also interferes with post-attachment steps required for the entry of HIV-1 virus particles into host cells and thus prevents the viral transmission that occurs via cell-cell fusion.

Option A: Ixekizumab is an IL-17A antagonist indicated in moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. 

Option C: Idarucizumab is a reversal agent for dabigatran.

Option D: Ipilimumab is a monoclonal antibody against CTLA-4 and acts as an immune checkpoint inhibitor.

questions.text: A patient with Prader-Willi syndrome needs to be evaluated for obesity but the scale for measuring height in your clinic is broken. Which of the following indices can you still use in this situation?
questions.solution:
The corpulence index can be used in this scenario as it is independent of height. The formula for corpulence index is actual weight/ desired weight.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density

questions.text: Acantholysis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Acantholysis is not seen in bullous pemphigoid as it is associated with subepidermal blistering.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.

Acantholysis is classified as:

Primary

Secondary
Rupture of the desmosome first, forming circular acantholytic cells Ballooning of the keratinocyte first, forming circular acantholytic cells (Tzank cell) 

Seen in: 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease

Seen in:

  • Herpes simplex infections (HSV-1 and 2)
  • Varicella-zoster infections (chickenpox, shingles)

The image below shows acantholysis (note the rounded and free-floating, detached keratinocytes).

questions.text: A woman presented to the clinic with redness and itching over the left breast as shown in the image below.  Histopathology showed large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and histology are suggestive of Paget's disease of the breast. 

Paget’s disease is a rare type of cancer involving the nipple-areolar complex, often with an underlying in-situ or invasive ductal carcinoma. It presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. Paget disease of the breast is often mistaken for eczema. 

  Paget's disease Eczema
Laterality Unilateral Bilateral
Age group Menopausal women Lactating women
Edges Distinct Indistinct
Vesicles Absent Present
Nipple Usually destroyed Usually intact
Lump Usually present No underlying lump 

A nipple biopsy specimen of Paget's disease will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei are pathognomonic for this condition.

Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Note: Histologically, Paget's disease can be confused with superficial spreading melanoma, particularly if they have incorporated melanin from adjacent epidermis. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.

questions.text: The antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is:
questions.solution:
Antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is emtricitabine.

It is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor similar to lamivudine. It has activity against HIV-1, HIV-2, and HBV.

questions.text: Which type of gastric ulcer has increased gastric acid levels?
questions.solution:
Gastric ulcers of Types II (gastric body with duodenal ulcer) and III (prepyloric) are associated with increased gastric acid levels.

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure

 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows: 

Modified Johnson classification for gastric ulcer

I. Lesser curve, incisura - Normal Acid secretion

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

V. Medication induced (NSAID/ acetylsalicylic acid), anywhere in stomach

questions.text: A 43-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia and secondary dysmenorrhea. On examination, Halban's sign was positive. The transvaginal USG findings are given below. Which of the following is the definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis is hysterectomy.

Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of subendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

The image below is of a sagittal MRI showing a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall. Gross enlargement of the posterior wall is noted, with many foci of hyperintensity.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with abnormal movements of the limbs. A lesion of the globus pallidus is suspected. Which of the following did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
This woman with a lesion at the globus pallidus most likely presented with athetosis: Slow, writhing movements of a hand/arm/the face. 

Condition Site of lesion Description

Severe rigidity, akinesia, and tremors

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe abdominal pain. On examination, his vitals are stable and there is abdominal rigidity and tenderness. The erect X-ray of the abdomen is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum and the patient is posted for emergency laparotomy. It reveals the presence of a perforated type I gastric ulcer. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Perform distal gastrectomy with Billroth I anastomosis
Closure of the perforation with Graham's patch repair

questions.solution:
In stable patients without operative risks, Perforated type I gastric ulcers are best managed by distal gastrectomy with Billroth I anastomosis (with or without vagotomy).       

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable or unfit for surgery, simple patch repair with biopsy preferred.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      

Type of Gastric Ulcer Management
Type I  Distal gastrectomy 
 Type II and III Distal gastrectomy + Vagotomy
 Type IV

 

 Csendes procedure

 or

questions.text: What does the Sin of Gomorrah refer to?
questions.solution:
Buccal coitus is also known as the sin of Gomorrah/ Coitus Per Os. The male genital organ is introduced into the mouth of another male or female.

Teeth marks or abrasions on the penis, semen in the respiratory tract/stomach could be the clues to diagnosis. Buccal swabs are useful for only up to 9 hours. Buccal coitus can lead to death by aspiration of semen or impaction of the penis in the hypopharynx.

Option A: Sodomy is anal intercourse between 2 males or between a male and a female. 

Option C: Incest is sexual intercourse between man and woman who are related by blood or a certain degree of blood relationship.

Option D: Bestiality is the sexual intercourse of a human being with a lower animal.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to _____.
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Schistosoma haematobium.

S. haematobium or vesical blood fluke is a trematode that lives in the pelvic and vesical venous plexuses. Its lifecycle involves man as a definitive host and freshwater snails as the intermediate host. Infective forms of schistosomes are fork-tailed cercaria larva. The eggs are non-operculated with a characteristic spine at one end.

The eggs are passed in the urine of the infected person, which will hatch in the water to release free-living ciliated miracidia. Miracidia then penetrate a suitable intermediate host and reaches its liver. In the liver, they produce first and second-generation sporocysts. The second generation sporocyst undergoes asexual reproduction producing cercaria larva. These are then released into the water. Persons become infected by contact with water containing cercariae during bathing. After entering the human body, they migrate through the heart and pulmonary circulation to reach the liver, where they attain sexual differentiation. From the liver, they reach the pelvic and vesical venous plexus, where they mature, mate, and lay eggs.

Clinical features include acute schistosomiasis in the form of skin rash at the site of penetration (swimmer's itch) or anaphylactic symptoms due to the release of toxic metabolites. Chronic schistosomiasis presents with chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the bladder leading to obstructive uropathies. There is an increased risk for bladder carcinoma and calculus formation.

Diagnosis : 

  • Detection of eggs in urine microscopy and bladder mucosal biopsy.
  • ELISA for antigen detection 
  • Detection of S. haematobium adult worm microsomal antigen (HAMA) by 
    • Falcon assay screening test (HAMAFAST) or ELISA
    • HAMA enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot (HAMA-EITB).
  • Intradermal skin testing (Fairley's test)

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

The following are the unique features distinguishing schistosomes from other trematodes:

  • Only one intermediate host.
  • They are unisexual/dioecious.
  • They produce non-operculated eggs.
  • Mode of infection is by penetration of intact skin with the help of forked tails of cercariae

Forms of most trematodes that are infective to humans are metacercaria larvae.

Related Pearl: Lifecycle of Schistosoma

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Difference between cestodes, trematodes, and nematodes

Not separate: hermaphrodite except Schistosoma

Separate (diecious)

questions.text: A patient developed a surgical site infection with Klebsiella, which is found to be sensitive to a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. Which of the following antibiotics is this likely to be?
questions.solution:
Cefepime is an antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Aminoglycosides, doxycycline, and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors. 

Related Pearl: Cell wall synthesis inhibitors (mnemonic "BBC Van")

BBC Van:

  • Beta lactams
  • Bacitracin
  • Cycloserine
  • Vancomycin
  • Fosfomycin

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the bony Bankart lesion?

choices.text: Avulsion fracture of the glenoid rim
Stripping of the antero-inferior glenoid labrum
Rupture of inferior glenohumeral ligament complex

questions.solution:
The bony bankart lesion is a small, avulsion fracture of the glenoid rim.

During an anterior shoulder dislocation, the head of the humerus can tear the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum. This is known as Bankart lesion. In some cases, a small fragment of bone from the glenoid rim can also get avulsed. This is known as a bony Bankart lesion.

Avulsion of posterior capsular periosteum is seen in reverse Bankart lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the major diagnostic triad of fat embolism syndrome (FES)?
questions.solution:
Fat globules in urine is a minor criterion in diagnosing fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is caused by the release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the bloodstream. It usually occurs following long bone or pelvic fractures, and multiple fractures.

Along with platelet aggregates, the globules result in the following manifestations which make up the major diagnostic triad:

  • Respiratory insufficiency
  • Neurological impairment
  • Petechial rash

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A 39-year-old nulliparous woman presented with dysmenorrhea and a progressively growing, painless abdominal mass. USG scan revealed a cystic lesion of the left ovary which was excised. The below image shows the excised specimen. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in endometriosis of ovary
It is lined by columnar epithelium
It is usually a bilateral condition
It is a malignant cystic lesion

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image is suggestive of a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is a benign cystic lesion.

Chocolate cysts of the ovary are a manifestation of endometriosis. Both the ovaries are usually affected. On histology, the cyst is lined by columnar epithelium. Pseudoxanthoma cells are present which are large macrophages or scavenger cells that appear brown in colour due to ingested blood pigments such as ­haemosiderin. They are polyhe­dral in shape and resemble lutein cells. 

Given below is a gross image of the chocolate cyst of the ovary.

Given below is a histopathological section of an endometriotic lesion showing the pseudoxanthoma cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about multiple myeloma?

choices.text: Increased monoclonal IgG1 causes hyperviscosity syndrome
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance mostly progresses to multiple myeloma
Radioisotope bone scanning can be used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
There is decreased anion gap in multiple myeloma due to the M protein. 

Anion gap in the serum is calculated as Na⁺ – (Cl– +HCO3–).

The M protein is cationic, resulting in the retention of chloride causing decreased anion gap.

Only 1% of patients with monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) go on to develop multiple myeloma. Hyperviscosity symptoms in multiple myeloma occurs due to excessive production of M proteins, usually of IgG3 or IgA subtype. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM myeloma) is the most common cause for hyperviscosity syndrome due to excess IgM paraprotein in these cases.

Radioisotopic bone scanning is less useful in diagnosis because the bone lesions are lytic in nature and are rarely associated with osteoblastic new bone formation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of a painless lump in her left breast which she noticed during a routine self-examination. On palpation, a hard lump with irregular margins and enlarged left axillary lymph nodes were found. Which among the following is the best modality to detect malignancy in her case?
questions.solution:
Tomosynthesis (3D mammography) performed along with conventional 2D mammography is the best investigation among the given options to detect breast carcinoma. 

Breast Tomosynthesis is typically performed in conjunction with conventional mammography. Hence, the radiation dose is doubled. However, the accuracy is improved and false positives are lesser. It can be used for dense breasts and those with high-risk factors.

Screen-film mammography is the conventional 2D mammography.

Digital mammography/full-field digital mammography uses digital technology instead of films. The diagnostic accuracy is similar to that of screen-film mammography. A minor advantage is the greater accuracy in predicting lesions in dense breasts.

Note: Overall, the best modality for detecting breast carcinoma is MRI.

The below image shows a comparison of 2D mammogram vs. 3D mammogram:

questions.text: What is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient regions?
questions.solution:
Follicular thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient areas.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas, children, and radiation-exposed areas.

  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma

The image shows plicae circulares which are also known as valvulae conniventes. They are more prominent in the jejunum.

Plicae circulares are the circular mucosal folds. They frequently branch and stack upon each other, giving the jejunum a characteristic feathery appearance in single contrast radiography.

questions.text: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying ____________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

Streptococci belonging to group A are identified (presumptively) by inhibition of growth by bacitracin.

questions.text: A man came to the casualty with severe pain over his thumb. He gave a history of a fall during a football match. X-ray done is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and radiograph point to a diagnosis of Bennett’s fracture.

Bennett's fracture is an oblique, simple intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

The given image shows Bennett's fracture.

Option B: Rolando’s fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal.

Option C: Boxer's fracture is the fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck.

Option D: Chauffeur fracture is a fracture of the radial styloid process.

questions.text: Tetrahydrobiopterin is a coenzyme for all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) is a coenzyme for the following enzymes:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase
  • Tyrosine hydroxylase
  • Tryptophan hydroxylase
  • Nitric oxide synthase

Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) resembles folic acid, but it is not a vitamin. It is derived from GTP.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: Which of the following is not an objective of the National Mental Health Programme of 1982?

choices.text: Ensure equal human rights to mentally ill
Promote community participation in mental health services
Promote application of mental health knowledge
Provide accessibility of mental health care

questions.solution:
Ensuring equal rights to mentally ill people is not an objective of the National Mental Health Programme (NMHP). It was launched in 1982 with the following objectives:

  • Ensure availability and accessibility of minimum mental health care
  • Encourage the application of mental health knowledge in general care
  • Promote community participation in mental health services development

The National Mental Health Programme was relaunched as The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 which includes provisions for equal rights for those with mental illness.

World Mental Health Day, observed on October 10th, highlights the importance of mental well-being. This year's theme, "It is Time to Prioritize Mental Health in the Workplace," stresses the need for businesses to foster supportive environments. Safe, healthy workplaces protect mental health, while stigma and poor conditions pose serious risks. By involving those with lived experiences and investing in evidence-based solutions, we can create workplaces where everyone thrives.

questions.text: A 47-year-old housewife presented with recurrent attacks of asthma and pain and numbness along the distribution of the median and ulnar nerve. Her serology was positive for pANCA. Further evaluation is unlikely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of asthma, mononeuritis multiplex, and pANCA positivity is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It affects small to medium-sized arteries. 

Laboratory investigations will show peripheral blood eosinophilia. Some patients may be positive for pANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies). Histopathology will show the presence of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas.

Histopathology of ANCA associated vasculitides can be remembered as:

  • Microscopic polyangiitis: necrotizing vasculitis
  • Wegener's granulomatosis: necrotizing vasculitis with granulomas
  • Churg Strauss syndrome: necrotizing vasculitis with extravascular granulomas and eosinophilia

questions.solution:

The posterior limb of internal capsule is supplied by:

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Northern blotting is used for the detection of RNA.

Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA and Western blotting is used for the detection of protein.

Northern blotting takes its name from its similarity to the first blotting technique, the Southern blot, named for biologist Edwin Southern.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image?

choices.text: It is more common in monochorionic pregnancies
It cannot be detected by sonography
It is diagnosed usually after delivery
Morbidity in the co-twin is due to hypotension

questions.solution:
The above image shows fetus compressus which appears as a tan ovoid mass compressed against the fetal membranes. It can be detected early by sonography.

In multifetal pregnancies, if one of the fetuses dies early in pregnancy, the surviving fetus continues to develop normally. It can lead to the following outcomes:

Outcome Type
Disappears Vanishing twin
Gets compressed Fetus compressus
Flattened through desiccation Fetus papyraceus

Factors affecting the prognosis of the surviving twin:

  • Gestational age at fetal death: 2nd and 3rd trimester deaths increase the risk of morbidity in the surviving twin
  • Chorionicity: Monochorionic twins with early fetal death have an increased risk of morbidity in the surviving twin. This is due to neurological abnormality and vascular anastomoses.
  • Duration between fetal demise and delivery of surviving twin
  • Surviving twin may be born preterm leading to an increased risk of fetal demise

Death in the surviving twin occurs mostly due to vascular anastomoses between the twins. The surviving twin can develop sudden hypotension due to these anatomoses after fetal demise.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the location of the otic ganglion?
questions.solution:
The secretomotor fibres from glossopharyngeal nerves relay through the otic ganglion before supplying the parotid gland. Otic ganglion is present medial to the mandibular nerve.

Relations of otic ganglion:

  • Superiorly - Foramen ovale
  • Laterally - Mandibular nerve
  • Medially - Tensor veli palatini
  • Posteriorly - Middle meningeal artery

Otic ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion which supplies secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and is present below the foramen ovale. 

  • Preganglionic fibres originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and pass through the lesser petrosal nerve which is the continuation of the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve. They relay in the otic ganglion.
  • Postganglionic fibres pass by the communicating branches to the auriculotemporal nerve and supply the parotid gland.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of antenatal visits?
questions.solution:
The ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14.

The antenatal visits should ideally be: monthly once up to 28 weeks, once in two weeks between 28-36 weeks, and once weekly visits from 36 weeks onwards.

This translates to a total of 12-15 visits.

The WHO increased the minimum number of antenatal visits from 4 to 8 visits to reduce perinatal mortality.

In the Indian scenario, the earlier minimum of 4 visits were implemented as follows:

  • 1st visit: within 12 weeks (preferably as soon as pregnancy is suspected)
  • 2nd visit: between 14-26 weeks
  • 3rd visit: between 28-34 weeks
  • 4th visit: between 36 weeks and term

A booked case is one that has at least 3 antenatal visits with two visits in the third trimester.

questions.text: A pregnant woman suffered a miscarriage at 6 months of gestation. What would be the expected crown heel length of this fetus?
questions.solution:
Crown heel length of a 6-month-old fetus would be 30 cm.

According to the rule of Hasse:

  • During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months.
  • During last five months, the length in centimeters is divided by five gives the age in months.

So, crown heel length = age in months × 5 (i.e. 6 × 5 = 30 cm).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about hair cycle?

choices.text: Anagen is responsible for final hair length
50% of hair is in anagen at any point in time
Lower part of the follicle involutes during catagen
Kenogen is a state of latency

questions.solution:
80-90% of hair follicles at a given time are in the anagen phase.

The hair cycle has three phases:

Anagen:

It refers to the period of active hair growth. Anagen can continue for several years and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair. Normally, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time. It can be identified by the presence of angulated roots.

Catagen:

At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division slows and stops, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen. The proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis. It lasts for about 3 weeks.

Telogen:

It is the resting phase between catagen and the next anagen. Clubbing becomes more prominent. It lasts for about 3 months. Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.

In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: Which of the following is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the fetal head for a woman in labor?
questions.solution:
The tone of levator ani muscles is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the head.

Prerequisites of internal rotation of the head are as follows:

  • Well-flexed head
  • Efficient uterine contraction
  • Favorable shape at mid-pelvic plane
  • Tone of the levator ani muscles

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman's body was retrieved from a manhole. You are suspecting antemortem drowning. Which of the following signs will most likely support your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm is an important sign of antemortem drowning. It manifests as closed hands with firmly grasped weed, grass, sticks, etc. floating in the water. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.

The image given below shows a cadaveric spasm of hand, holding grass, as seen in antemortem drowning.

questions.text: An electrician experienced a 10,000 V shock through his body and suffered third-degree burns on his hands and scalp. Diffusion tensor imaging showed damage to the right medial lemniscus tract. This is formed by:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of medial lemniscus tract lesion following a high voltage electrical injury. The medial lemniscus is formed by the internal arcuate fibres. It is also called Reil's ribbon.

The internal arcuate fibres are axons of the second-order neurons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus. In the upper medulla, they decussate and form the medial lemniscus which synapses in the thalamus. 

The image given below depicts the medial lemniscus tract.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.

This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is least likely to be seen in a patient with an intestinal type of gastric cancer?

choices.text: Loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene
Under expression of transforming growth factor α
Loss of heterozygosity at the bcl-2 gene

questions.solution:
In the intestinal type of gastric cancer, several growth factors may be overexpressed, including transforming growth factor α, the epidermal growth factor, and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

Molecular pathologies seen in Intestinal type:

  • Mutation or loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene or in β-catenin
  • Inactivation of p53
  • Loss of heterozygosity at the BCL-2 gene
  • Microsatellite instability

Molecular pathologies seen in diffuse-type: 

  • Mutation of E- cadherin
  • Inactivation of p53
