questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the resting membrane potential (RMP) in a nerve fibre?

choices.text: It is equal to the RMP of inner hair cells of cochlea
It can be measured by surface electrodes
It becomes more positive as extracellular K+ increases
It depends on the equilibrium potential of Na+

questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential is close to the equilibrium potential for K+. So, changes in the external concentration of this ion can have major effects on the resting membrane potential.

  • If the extracellular level of K+ is increased (hyperkalemia), the resting potential moves closer to the threshold for eliciting an action potential, thus the neuron becomes more excitable.
  • If the extracellular level of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), the membrane potential is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

Option a: The RMP of a nerve fiber is -70 mV, while the RMP of inner hair cells is between -45 and -60 mV relative to the fluid that bathes the basal end of the cell.

Option b: The membrane potential can be measured only when one electrode is inserted into the interior of the cell.

Option d: It depends on the equilibrium potential of K+.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with complaints of persistent dry eyes and dry mouth since past few months. On examination, dry mucous membranes, bilateral parotid region swelling, and conjunctivitis were noted. This condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Dry eyes and dry mouth along with parotid swelling and conjunctivitis are suggestive of Sjögren’s syndrome. It is associated with HLA-DR3 allele.

HLA allele Disease
HLA DR2, HLA-DR3 SLE

HLA-B27 Seronegative arthritis

questions.text: Which is the first steroid to be produced in cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
Lanosterol is the first steroid to be synthesized in cholesterol synthesis.

  • Cyclization of squalene gives rise to the parent steroid, lanosterol.
  • The formation of cholesterol from lanosterol involves changes in the steroid nucleus and the side chain.

questions.solution:
Glucose transporter specific to the transport of fructose from the intestine to enterocytes is GLUT 5. It is present in small intestine, testis, and sperm, and it primarily transports fructose.

questions.text: To assess the vitamin B1 nutritional status in a patient, measurement of which of the following can be used?
questions.solution:
Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status.

Transketolase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and requires Mg2+ and thiamine diphosphate (vitamin B1) as cofactors. In thiamine deficiency, the RBC transketolase activity is reduced. When thiamine diphosphate is added in-vitro to erythrocyte lysate, activation of apo-transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

Other enzymes requiring thiamine as a cofactor are:
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Transketolase
Options A and B: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase are involved in the oxidative phase of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway. Both enzymes require NADP+ and contribute to the formation of NADPH and ribose.
 
Option D: The vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: What is the best indicator of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
The perinatal mortality rate is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal tubular acidosis can develop in individuals with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Type IV renal tubular acidosis (RTA) may occur in individuals with diabetes mellitus types 1 and 2.

Type IV RTA occurs due to hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism. Low plasma renin activity is common in diabetic patients due to:

  • Impaired conversion of prorenin to renin
  • Volume expansion in diabetic nephropathy suppresses renin release

These individuals have a tendency to develop hyperkalemia and acidemia, which can be exacerbated by the use of ACEI and ARBs. Hence, these drugs should be avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is tested in Breslau’s second life test?
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test, also known as the stomach bowel test, the stomach and the duodenum are tested.

This test is done to determine whether the baby was born alive or not.

It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live-born child. Detecting the presence of this air in these viscera constitutes the basis for this test.

Procedure :

The stomach and duodenum are removed separately and placed in water. If they float, make a small cut while underwater to see air bubbles coming up. A floating viscera giving out air bubbles when opened underwater is a positive test.

Interpretation:

  • A positive test proves live birth even in the absence of a positive hydrostatic lung test. This may happen if there had been some obstruction in the respiratory passages.
  • A negative test does not mean stillbirth since air does not necessarily enter the stomach in adequate amounts during the breathing act.
  • Putrefaction invalidates the result.

Note: Breslau’s first life test is when the same test is performed on the lungs. Also known as Hydrostatic test/ Floatation test / Raygat’s test.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with involuntary, sudden jerking movements of both upper limbs. They occur most frequently in the morning after awakening and are provoked by a lack of sleep. EEG demonstrates bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow- wave discharges. Which of the following features is not seen in this type of seizure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myoclonic seizures. Post-ictal paralysis is not seen in these seizures.

Myoclonic seizures are characterized by preserved consciousness (rarely very short loss of consciousness), preserved postural control, Lack of postictal confusion.

Myoclonic seizures usually coexist with other forms of generalized seizures but are the predominant feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). The EEG shows bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow wave discharges. 

JME or Janz's syndrome is an epilepsy syndrome that has familial inheritance and begins in adolescence. It most commonly occurs in the morning and is provoked by sleep deprivation. JME is usually associated with GTCS and sometimes with absence seizures. EEG shows a typical 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave pattern. Treatment includes administration of sodium valproate.

questions.text: A patient has a history of multiple episodes of painful swelling of ankles and big toes which is relieved with NSAIDs. You would avoid all of the following drugs in her except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario of multiple painful swelling of ankles and toes that responded to NSAIDs is suggestive of gout. High-dose salicylates (>3g/day) do not precipitate gout.

Although high-dose salicylates inhibit both the secretion and reabsorption of urate, the inhibition of reabsorption is more than the inhibition of secretion, and therefore the net effect is uricosuric.

On the other hand, low-dose salicylates (<2 to 3g/day) are associated with uric acid retention. They inhibit renal tubular secretion of uric acid resulting in hyperuricemia and may precipitate gout. 

Aspirin is not used to treat acute attacks of gout due to its uric acid retention property. However, low-dose aspirin used for cardiovascular prophylaxis need not be discontinued during the treatment of a gout flare.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: As a part of the iodine deficiency control programme, you advocate the usage of iodized salt in hilly areas. What is this type of prevention an example of?
questions.solution:
The usage of iodized salt in iodine-deficient areas like in hilly regions is an example of primary prevention as it provides specific protection.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed every year on 21st October to raise awareness about the fair use of iodine, to highlight the factors that lead to iodine deficiency and its consequences. Iodine deficiency disorders are the world’s most prevalent yet easily preventable disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest cause of pathological nipple discharge in a non-lactating woman?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of nipple discharge in a non-lactating woman is duct ectasia. The discharge is usually black or greenish in color.

Option B: Intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge. It is a true polyp of the epithelium-lined ducts of the breast. Contrary to what one might expect, they are not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.

Option C: Paget's disease of the breast can present with discharge from the surface of the nipple.

Option D: Galactorrhea is the milk production from breasts unrelated to pregnancy or lactation.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: Gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is_______.
questions.solution:
A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.

  • It shows the following:
    • Absent ganglia
    • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
    • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
    • Calretinin immunostain­ing: superior to acetylcholinesterase staining.

 

Option D: Anorectal manometry is an important screening tool. It shows the absence of rectoanal inhibitory reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.

Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square compared to the outer circle.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A study conducted among smokers shows that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking. Which of the following variables indicates this?
questions.solution:
Attributable risk indicates to what extent the disease under study can be attributed to the exposure. Here, cigarette smoking is attributed to be the cause of 80% of lung cancers in smokers.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Breast milk is superior to cow’s milk because ________

choices.text: Casein is 60% of the protein content
Whey is 70% of the protein content

questions.solution:
Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The Whey: Casein ratio in human milk fluctuates between 70:30 and 80:20. This ratio is 20:80 in cow's milk. The high fraction of soluble whey protein in breast milk makes it easily digestible.

The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk. Human milk contains amino acids like taurine and cysteine (lacking in cow’s milk), which are necessary for neurotransmission and neuromodulation.

Breast milk is rich in polyunsaturated fat (not saturated fat), which is necessary for myelination. Human breast milk is generally rich in oleic acid and linoleic acid.

Sodium concentration is not high in breast milk. It has a low osmolality, and hence, the solute load on the kidneys is low.

Differences between human milk and cow's milk are shown below:

Nutrient Human milk (per 100 mL) Cow's milk (per 100 mL)
Protein 1.1 g 3.5 g
Calories 67 kcal 62 kcal
Casein 30–40% (rich in whey protein) 80%
Lactose 7.4 g 4.5 g
Fat  3.5 g 4g
Na+ (mEq/L) 6.5 25
K+ (mEq/L) 14 35
Osmolality (mOsm/L) 290 350
calcium/phosphate >2 <2
Vitamin K 1.5 µg 6 µg
Iron 0.29–0.45 mg 0.01-0.38 mg
Vitamin D 0.5-10 IU 0.5-4.5 IU

questions.text: Which subtype of acute myeloid leukemia presents with disseminated intravascular coagulation as a paraneoplastic manifestation?
questions.solution:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) as a paraneoplastic syndrome is most commonly associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) and prostatic adenocarcinoma.

Major determinants of coagulopathy in APL are endogenous factors of the malignant leukemic cells and their interaction with host defense mechanisms.

Factors that cause coagulopathy include:

  • Increased expression of procoagulant activity (PCA)
  • Expression of fibrinolytic and proteolytic properties
  • Secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines - interleukin-1b (IL-1b) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast was advised to undergo mammography which was reported as BIRADS 3. What will be the appropriate next step of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
A BIRADS score of 3 means that it is probably a benign lesion. The next appropriate step is to follow up with this patient every 6 months for the next 2 years.

During this period, the score can either downgrade to BIRADS 2 or upgrade to BIRADS 4 or 5.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up

2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening

4

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Spigelian hernia is false?

choices.text: It occurs above the level of the arcuate line
The hernia sac is posterior to the external oblique aponeurosis
Most commonly presents as a painless mass

questions.solution:
Usually, Spigelian hernias do not present as a mass because it is beneath the intact external oblique aponeurosis.

The most common presentation in Spigelian hernia is pain.

There is a common misconception that they protrude below the arcuate line owing to the deficiency of the posterior rectus sheath at that level; but in fact, the defect is almost always above the arcuate line.

Related Pearl: Spigelian hernia/Hernia of linea semilunaris:

  • Occurs through the spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. 
  • This aponeurotic layer is  between the rectus muscle medially and semilunar line laterally.
  • Occur at or above the arcuate line.
  • Often interparietal, with the hernia sac dissecting pos­terior to the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • In subumbilical region and is due to defect in internal oblique.
  • Clinical feature:
    • Often present with localized pain in the area without a bulge because the hernia lies beneath the intact external oblique aponeurosis. 
  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound or CT of the abdomen.
  • Treatment – surgery

questions.text: Which of the following dietary recommendation puts patients at risk of developing colon cancer?
questions.solution:
High-calorie, low-fiber, and high-animal-fat diet as well as alcohol consumption increase the risk of colon cancer.

Calcium, selenium, vitamins A, C, and E, carotenoids, and plant phenols are protective.

Implication of low-fiber diet as a risk factor for colon carcinoma is unclear with different cohort and case–control studies giving conflicting findings. Hence, option A has been changed from low-fiber diet  to high-caloric diet as a risk factor.

questions.text: Which is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Symptomatic atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life. 

Treatment of atrial fibrillation in HCM:

  • Amiodarone - drug of choice
  • Disopyramide
  • Radiofrequency ablation for medically refractory cases
  • Anticoagulation to prevent embolic events

Note: A sustained arrhythmia is one that lasts for >30 seconds.

questions.text: A post-coital test was done in a couple who presented with an inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. Which of the following conditions cannot be detected by this test?
questions.solution:
The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions:

  • Sperm count
  • Sperm morphology
  • Ferning during the estrogenic effect
  • Ovulation
  • The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration
  • Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucous

In the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to the ovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control.

On microscopy, 10–50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucus is also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence of cervical infection.

An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.

questions.text: A 54-year-old school teacher presented with a chief complaint of pain in the eyes and intermittent blurry vision which was worse in the mornings. Generalized corneal haze was noted in both eyes but was more significant in the left. Examination findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with beaten metal appearance on slit lamp and reduced endothelial cell density with coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, slowly progressive, often asymmetric corneal disease. It is characterized by deterioration of endothelial cells and development of guttata, which are excrescences of Descemet’s membrane (seen on specular or confocal microscopy). Females are affected more than males. It is more common in the 4th decade or later. 

Endothelial layer dysfunction causes loss of corneal deturgescence, and bilateral oedema of the stroma, leading to ocular pain, glare, halos, and decreased visual acuity. Patients have a worse vision in the morning because of the eyes being closed during the night causing a buildup of corneal oedema.

Stages of Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy:

  • Stage 1: Central corneal guttata that spreads peripherally
  • Stage 2: Corneal oedema - beaten metal-like appearance 
  • Stage 3: Bullous keratopathy
  • Stage 4: Subepithelial scarring and superficial vascularization

Treatment:

  • Conservative option- topical hypertonic (saline sodium chloride 5% drops or 6% ointment) and bandage contact lenses.
  • The definitive treatment is endothelial keratoplasty: Descemet’s stripping endothelial keratoplasty (DSEK/DSAEK) or Descemet membrane Endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK).

 

Related Pearl: Types of Corneal Dystrophies

Epithelial

  • Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD)
  • Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy
  • Meesman’s dystrophy
  • Lisch’s epithelial dystrophy
  • Gelatinous drop-like dystrophy

Bowman’s Membrane

  • Reis Buckler’s dystrophy
  • Thiel-Behnke corneal dystrophy
  • Grayson-Wilbrandt corneal dystrophy

  • Granular dystrophy
  • Macular corneal dystrophy
  • Schnyder corneal dystrophy
  • Fleck corneal dystrophy
  • Posterior amorphous corneal dystrophy
  • Central cloudy dystrophy of Francois

Descemet membrane and Endothelial corneal dystrophy

  • Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy
  • Posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy (PPCD)
  • Congenital hereditary endothelial
  • X-linked endothelial corneal dystrophy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a NS5A inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Simeprevir is a HCV NS3 protease inhibitor.

NS5A inhibitors: Usually used in combination with NS5B inhibitor and/or NS3 protease inhibitors.  

  • Ledipasvir
  • Daclatasvir
  • Velpatasvir 
  • Ombitasvir
  • Elbasvir

questions.text: An elderly male patient is diagnosed with direct inguinal hernia. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The sac lies medial to the inferior epigastric artery
Cough impulse is felt on the index finger
Can descend till the bottom of scrotum
The neck is narrow and is prone for strangulation

questions.solution:
The sac and contents of a direct hernia protrude through Hesselbach’s triangle, i.e., medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors is bound and activated by tissue factor?
questions.solution:
The tissue factor binds and activates factor VII.

Tissue factor is produced by the subendothelial cells in the vessel wall such as vascular smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts. It is a membrane-bound procoagulant glycoprotein.

Secondary hemostasis involves a sequence of events, which results in the polymerization of fibrin. This is achieved by cross-linking fibrin monomers into insoluble strands that serve to stabilize the loose platelet clot formed in primary hemostasis.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following renal biopsy specimen. What does it show?

choices.text: Proliferating  parietal and visceral epithelial  cells and WBCs in Bowman space
Diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall
Proliferating mesangial cells and increased matrix deposition in the mesangium
Proliferation of capillaries with fibrin deposition

questions.solution:
The given image shows a crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial cells and leukocytes within the Bowman capsule. It is a characteristic feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or crescentic glomerulonephritis.

RPGN is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and formation of crescents. It is usually immune-mediated and may be associated with circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), anti-GBM antibodies, and antinuclear antibodies (ANA).

Injury to the glomerular capillary wall leads to the escape of procoagulant factors and cytokines in the Bowman space. This triggers:

  • Proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells - mostly parietal, but also some visceral cells 
  • Recruitment of leukocytes and fibroblasts 
  • Pathognomonic crescents - due to the circumferential accumulation of these cells and fibrin

The crescents progressively compress the capillary tuft. This results in a rapid decline of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and, consequently, acute kidney injury (AKI). Thus, the degree of crescent formation correlates with the severity and the prognosis of the disease.

Related Pearl: Types of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

Type I (Anti-GBM Antibody)

Renal limited

Goodpasture syndrome

Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3

IgA nephropathy

Others: Cryoglobulinemia, Bacterial endocarditis, sepsis, acute pancreatitis/advanced liver disease

Type III (Pauci-Immune)

ANCA-associated

Idiopathic

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)

Immunofluorescence: No immunoglobulin or complement deposits

 

Image: Crescentic glomerulonephritis (PAS stain) with the crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal epithelial cells and leukocytes internal to Bowman capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-inflammatory cytokine?
questions.solution:
IL-4 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine.

It induces alternatively activated macrophages. This results in tissue repair and the resolution of inflammation.

The following are anti-inflammatory cytokines:

  • IL-4
  • IL-10
  • IL-13
  • TGF-β
  • Lipoxins

Lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting leukocyte recruitment. They inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources

IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

  3. VEGF:

questions.text: You are administering a polysaccharide vaccine against typhoid fever to a child in Germany before his trip to India. Which of the following is false about the antigen used in this vaccine?
questions.solution:
The polysaccharide vaccine against typhoid fever uses Vi capsule polysaccharide antigen. It is a heat-labile antigen.

Vi antigen is found in Salmonella typhi, S. paratyphi C and S. dublin. It is a capsular antigen and is a polysaccharide. It acts as a virulence factor by inhibiting phagocytosis and resisting complement activation and bacterial lysis. It envelopes the O antigen, and thus, many S. typhi strains fail to agglutinate with O antiserum. However, it can be destroyed by heat. It is alcohol stable. This antigen is poorly immunogenic.

The Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine (Vi CPS) contains purified Vi capsular polysaccharide. It is given as a single dose of 0.5 ml intramuscularly to children over 2 years of age. It is recommended for travellers to areas endemic for Salmonella infections.

questions.text: Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of_____

choices.text: Increased Na + concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Cl - concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Na + concentration in macula densa
Increased Cl- concentration in macula densa

questions.solution:
Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of increased Na+ concentration in macula densa.

Macula densa are the specialized cells present at the distal end of the thick ascending loop of Henle where it reaches the glomerulus. Distal convoluted tubule starts from macula densa. Macula forms part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

While both Na+ and Cl- are delivered to the macula densa cells, it is the increased concentration of Na+ in the cells that increases the Na+-K ATPase activity leading to the feedback.

questions.text: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis(RA) is subcutaneous nodules.

The nodules are generally benign, non-tender, and firm, and occur in areas subjected to repeated trauma such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. They can also occur in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. 

Patients who have a history of cigarette smoking had early onset arthritic manifestations and tested positive for RA factor or ACPA are more likely to develop extra-articular manifestations. Other common extra-articular manifestations include secondary Sjogren's syndrome, interstitial lung disease, pulmonary nodules, and anemia. FELTY’S syndrome is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular RA.

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Spine involvement Cervical spine
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)
Cardiac manifestation Pericarditis
Valvular abnormality Mitral regurgitation
Pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
Hematological manifestation Normochromic normocytic anemia
Neurological manifestation Compression neuropathies (mostly carpal tunnel syndrome)
Ocular manifestation  Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Lymphoma Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Cause of death Cardiovascular disease (coronary artery disease)

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Six’s thermometer.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true with respect to the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

choices.text: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge
Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants with immature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.solution:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period of time. 

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm, late preterm, and term infants for supplementation. It is economic, cheap, and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. 

Feeding tubes- orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It requires frequent replacement.

Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a risk of aspiration.

World Breastfeeding Week is a global campaign celebrated 1-7 August every year. World Breastfeeding Week aims to highlight the benefits that breastfeeding can bring to both the health and welfare of babies, as well as for maternal health. The theme for the year 2022 is "Step Up for Breastfeeding: Educate and Support".

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?

choices.text: The dermis is 3–4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d’orange appearance of the skin can be seen
Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds phenomenon

questions.solution:
Scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds Phenomenon. Scleredema and scleroderma are different entities. In contrast to systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes, or serum autoantibodies.

In scleredema, the dermis is 3–4 times thicker than normal due to an increase in type 1 collagen synthesis by dysfunctional fibroblast. However, fibroblast proliferation is not seen.

Erythema and a peau d’orange appearance of the skin are commonly observed. The hands and feet are characteristically spared.

Diabetic scleredema is the most common type. In diabetic scleredema, the accumulation of collagen may be due to irreversible non‐enzymatic glycosylation of collagen and resistance to degradation by collagenase. It can also occur post-streptococcal infections.

questions.text: The following image shows a nephrectomy specimen of a patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. What is the likely histopathological finding in this tumor?

choices.text: Small cells with high N/C ratio

questions.solution:
The given image shows a bright yellow variegated mass distorting the renal outline at the lower pole. This is suggestive of the clear cell type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The yellow color is due to prominent lipid accumulation.

Gross findings of various types of renal tumors:

 

Clear-cell RCC

 Papillary RCC Chromophobe RCC Oncocytoma Angiomyolipoma
Site of origin Proximal tubular epithelium

Proximal tubule

Intercalated cells of collecting ducts

Intercalated cells of collecting ducts

Perivascular epithelioid cells (PEComa)

Multifocal and bilateral

 Solitary, unilateral Usually solitary Mostly solitary, can be multifocal
Color

Golden yellow, due to the high lipid content of their cells

Light tan to brown

Yellow to pinkish-tan, depending on the relative proportions of the various components
Capsule

Pseudocapsule+

questions.text: A 56-year-old​ female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A patient with the given history and barium swallow findings of irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins of esophagus, are suggestive of carcinoma esophagus.

Esophageal carcinoma is more common in men, with tobacco use and alcohol being the strongest risk factors. The squamous cell carcinoma variant usually affects the upper 2/3rd, and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower 1/3rd of the esophagus. Clinical features include progressive dysphagia (most common), regurgitation of food, vomiting, odynophagia and weight loss.

On barium swallow, carcinoma esophagus presents with irregular narrowing and ulceration of esophagus. Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

Other options: 

Option B:  Diffuse esophageal spasm results in the corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on barium study.

Option C: Esophageal leiomyoma appears as a smooth, semilunar filling defect on barium swallow. it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium. 

Option D: Esophageal webs occur in the upper and middle esophagus as a thin membrane that can be identified by the translucent part on contrast radiology. 


 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman falls in the bathroom and hurts her head. She regains her consciousness after a few minutes and continues with her daily activities. After 3 hours, she again becomes unconscious and collapses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes lucid interval and it is classically associated with extradural/ epidural hemorrhage (EDH). 

Patients with EDH present with 3 phases:

  • The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. 
  • The patient then awakens and has a lucid interval while the hematoma sub-clinically expands.
  • As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and unconscious.

A lucid interval is a period of normal consciousness and here the person is legally bound by the laws that affect normal people.

The image given below shows the intracranial hemorrhages.

questions.text: A male infant with a birth weight of 3.2 Kg is admitted to the phototherapy unit with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dl at 36 hours of life. Which of the following statements does not describe pathological jaundice?

choices.text: Jaundice appears within first 24 hours after birth
Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks
Jaundice associated with rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dl/24 hour
Jaundice seen in the mid-abdomen and soles

questions.solution:
Jaundice associated with a rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dL/24 hours suggests physiological jaundice.

Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

  • Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth
  • Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant
  • Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level
  • Total serum bilirubin levels above the expected normal range; jaundice seen in the mid-abdominal region (≈ 15 mg/dL) and soles (≈ 20 mg/dL)
  • Total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy
  • Total serum bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the type of cartilage shown in the histological image below?

choices.text: It is present in epiphyseal plate

questions.solution:
The above image shows a section of fibrocartilage stained with trichrome stain. Fibrocartilage is not covered by perichondrium.

The fibrocartilage is an intermediate between dense fibrous connective tissue (tendon and ligaments) and hyaline cartilage. It consists of bundles of thick collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles.

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by:

  • Presence of chondrocytes
  • Matrix containing abundant collagen fibres

Options A & D: Both the epiphyseal plate and bronchi have the hyaline type of cartilage.

Note: The colour of cartilage should not be considered while deciding its type, as it largely depends on the type of stain used. Instead, the structure or organisation of the cartilage tissue should be considered.

questions.text: Who first coined the term social medicine?
questions.solution:
Jules Guérin coined this term as editor of the Gazette médicale de Paris. He was a French orthopaedist in the mid-1800s.

Option A: John Ryle promoted social medicine in England in the early 1900s.

Option C: Alfred Grotjahn described social pathology, the social factors influencing diseases.

Option D: Francis Albert Eley Crew stated that social medicine stood on the pillars of medicine and sociology.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with thunderclap headaches and seizures. There is no history of trauma. Non-contrast CT was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a thunderclap headache and seizures with the given CT scan showing hyperdense areas corresponding to blood in the subarachnoid basal cisterns suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

Patients present with a sudden and severe headache referred to as thunderclap headache, which may be associated with vomiting, decreased consciousness, and seizures. Neck stiffness and photophobia may develop after a few hours.

Non-contrast CT scan is the imaging modality of choice if done within 12 hours. It shows an increased density of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. A lumbar puncture should be done if there is a strong suspicion of SAH but negative CT findings. It is ideally done 12 hours later. This allows for red blood cell lysis to occur and bilirubin to be detected in the CSF.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is present in skeletal muscles, but absent in a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But troponin is absent and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida, at 4-months period of gestation and history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, visits your clinic. She has been regularly taking sodium valproate and is now concerned about the medication possibly affecting her child. What would you suggest to this patient?

choices.text: Immediately taper valproate and start lamotrigine
Continue valproate with serial drug monitoring

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient should be advised to continue valproate, and serial drug monitoring should be done. 

Valproate has a higher teratogenic potential. It is usually avoided before conception if other antiepileptics with less teratogenicity (lamotrigine. levetiracetam) can be used. But for a woman who is pregnant and is already taking valproate, changing the drug is not recommended.

Option A - The patient is presenting in the second trimester when organogenesis would have been complete. Therefore, tapering the drug and introducing lamotrigine is not an option as precipitating seizures has a greater risk of fetal harm at this stage.

Option C: Carbamazepine is not indicated in JME as it may worsen the myoclonic jerks and absence seizures. 

Option D- Adding additional drugs to stabilized doses may increase teratogenicity. So adding lamotrigine to valproate is also not a viable option.

questions.text: Due to an effective prevention program, the prevalence of a disease in a community has been reduced by 90%. However, the physicians continue to use the same screening test for that disease. Which of the following changes is expected to be seen?
questions.solution:
If the prevalence of the disease falls, the negative predictive value(NPV) increases.

The NPV of the test is inversely proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

The PPV of the test is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

Sensitivity and specificity are independent of the prevalence of the disease in the area. They do not change with the change in prevalence. 

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: Pneumatic retinopexy is an outpatient procedure where retinal detachment is sealed with air insufflation. Which of the following gases would you use while performing the said procedure?
questions.solution:
Sulphur hexafluoride is the gas used in pneumatic retinopexy for the treatment of retinal detachments

Pneumatic retinopexy is used for the treatment of fresh retinal detachments with a single retinal break in the superior two-thirds of the fundus. In this procedure, a bubble is injected intravitreally through the conjunctiva and postoperatively the patient is positioned so that the bubble tamponades the retinal break against the retinal pigment epithelium.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman underwent a screening colonoscopy. A single polyp is found, resected, and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following biopsy findings will have the highest risk of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy.

Adenomatous polyps can be tubular, tubulovillous, and villous adenomas. Among these, tubular adenoma has the least risk and villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy.

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.solution:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.

It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. 

Diagnosis:

  • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
  • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.

The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:

  • Grade 1: <50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: No lumen detected

Other options

  • Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.
  • Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.
  • Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented to the clinic for a routine clinical check-up. On examination, his BP was found to be 136/88 mmHg. During his subsequent visits, the systolic blood pressure recorded was found to be within the range of 130-138 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure was within the range of 86-88mmHg. According to the European guidelines for hypertension 2018, his blood pressure would be classified as ____________
questions.solution:
According to European guidelines for hypertension 2018, systolic blood pressure between 130-139 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure between 85-89 mmHg is classified as high normal.

Related Pearl: Classification of blood pressure for adults - European Society of Cardiology guidelines - 2018

Classification of Office blood pressure

Normal

85-89

100-109

Isolated systolic hypertension ≥140 and <90

Note: Whenever hypertension can be classified into two different categories based on values of SBP and DBP, then the higher category is considered as the classification of hypertension.

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.

Fragile X syndrome is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation (Down syndrome being the most common). It is caused by a trinucleotide mutation, characterised by multiple tandem repeats of the CGG sequence in the familial mental retardation-1 (FMR1) gene. It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family.

The affected males are mentally retarded, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60.

The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Macro-orchidism
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • High arched palate
  • Mitral valve prolapse

When the cells were cultured in a folate-deficient medium, the cytogenetic alteration was discovered as a break in the staining in the long arm of the X chromosome. Because it appeared that the chromosome was “broken” at this locale, it was named as a fragile site.

The given image shows a child suffering from fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. He admitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a brownish moiré pattern that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coli.

Bisacodyl is also implicated in causing melanosis coli.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of growth hormone (GH) deficiency?
questions.solution:
Hyperglycemia is not a characteristic of GH deficiency. Isolated GH deficiency, especially in children, can lead to a higher propensity to develop hypoglycemia. This is attributed to the relatively unopposed action of insulin. 

Isolated GH deficiency in children is associated with the following features:

  • Short stature
  • Micropenis
  • Increased fat
  • High-pitched voice
  • High propensity to develop hypoglycemia due to relatively unopposed insulin action.

questions.text: A budding athlete who is keen to participate in long races visits his dietician for a discussion on his exercise capacity. When an athlete runs at a speed typical for the marathon race,  the time until complete exhaustion is maximal with which of the following diets?
questions.solution:
When athletes run at speeds typical for the marathon race, the time that they can sustain the race until complete exhaustion (also known as endurance) is maximal with a high-carbohydrate diet.

A person, who consumes a high-carbohydrate diet, stores far more glycogen in muscles than does a person who consumes either a mixed diet or a high-fat diet. Therefore, endurance is enhanced by a high-carbohydrate diet.

When athletes run at speeds typical for the marathon race, their endurance is approximately the following:

Diet Minutes

High-carbohydrate diet 

 240
 Mixed diet 120
 High-fat diet 85

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about spasmodic dysphonia?

choices.text: May be associated with other dystonias
Abductor type produces breathy voice and adductor type produces strangulated voice
Botulinum toxin is used in treatment

questions.solution:
Spasmodic dysphonia is not only a local laryngeal disorder. It is associated with many neurological conditions too.

There are 2 types of spasmodic dysphonia:

Adductor dysphonia

  • The adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to go into adduction. The voice becomes strained/strangled. 
  • Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in the thyroarytenoid muscles on one or both sides to relieve the spasm.

Abductor dysphonia

  • It is due to the spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle and thus the glottis is kept open.
  • The patient gets a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice.

Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. Patients who do not respond to toxin injection can be treated by type 1 thyroplasty or fat injection.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a lump in her right breast for the past 6 months. On examination, the lump is around 1 x1 cm in size, firm, and freely movable on the breast tissue. Ultrasound shows the presence of a circumscribed oval lobulated mass. Which of the following is not true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Peak incidence is in second decade
It is a form of ANDI

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of fibroadenoma. Mammography may show the presence of popcorn calcification. Eggshell calcification can be seen in traumatic fat necrosis.

Fibroadenoma is a form of aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade. It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, solitary, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on FNAC.

Giant fibroadenoma is more than 5cm in size and is common in adolescent girls. It requires excision by submammary incision.

The image below shows popcorn calcification on mammography:

Based on the recent update from the 10th edition of Robins, two-thirds of fibroadenomas harbor driver mutations in MED12. The pathogenesis of the remainder is uncertain.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?

choices.text: BP increases with age in all individuals
BP falls steadily in the elderly
Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.solution:
If the blood pressure of individuals is followed up over years from early childhood to adult life, low blood pressures tend to remain low and high blood pressures become higher as the individuals grow older. This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure is described as tracking.

This is helpful in identifying children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities have been identified whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intake and calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man sustained a roller crush injury of his left arm up to mid-humerus and was brought to the casualty. The duty orthopedician uses the MESS score to decide about limb salvage. The score does not include which of the following?
questions.solution:
Neurogenic injury is not included in the Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS).

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is useful in deciding about limb salvage.

The components of the Mangled Extremity Severity score are:

  • The energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Age of the patient.

Related Pearl: Mangled Extremity Severity Score

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presented with chest pain and fatigue. The chest radiograph is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows calcified pericardium, called an egg-in-cup appearance. It is typically seen in constrictive pericarditis.

In constrictive pericarditis, there is fibrous or calcific constrictive thickening of the anterior and lateral pericardium that prevents normal diastolic filling of the heart. The resulting diastolic dysfunction leads to features of right heart failure. The thickness of the pericardium is best assessed on MRI.

Note: The egg-in-cup (or ball-on-tee) appearance is also a urographic finding seen in renal papillary necrosis.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is upto 6 hours. TRALI is sudden-onset respiratory failure that occurs during or soon after blood transfusion. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia

  • Transient hypotension
