questions.text: Among the following, which is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Cushing’s syndrome is most commonly caused by ectopic ACTH production.

Among endogenous causes of Cushing’s syndrome, ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome makes up 90% of total cases. Based on the source of ACTH, there are two causes:

  • Cushing’s disease (ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma) – 75 %
  • Ectopic ACTH production – 15 %

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following forms complex I of the electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Complex I of the electron transport chain (ETC) is NADH-Q oxidoreductase.

The ETC constitutes 4 enzyme complexes:

  • Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase
  • Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase
  • Complex III: Q-cytochrome c oxidoreductase
  • Complex IV: cytochrome c oxidase

Components of complex I are FMN and Fe-S complex. NADH-Q oxidoreductase catalyzes the transfer of electrons, from NADH to coenzyme Q, along with the transfer of four H+ across the membrane.

But, this occurs by means of the electrons being transferred from NADH to FMN initially, and from then on, through a series of Fe-S centers, to finally reach coenzyme Q, then to complex III.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intraembryonic mesoderm is false?

choices.text: It is also known as secondary mesoderm
It Is formed from the epiblast cells
It spreads throughout the embryonic disc
Most of the body tissues are formed from mesoderm

questions.solution:
The intraembryonic mesoderm spreads throughout the embryonic disc, except in the region of the prechordal plate and cloacal membrane. In these two regions, the ectoderm is in direct contact with the endoderm. 

 The image given below shows the direct contact of intraembryonic mesoderm with the endoderm.

The intraembryonic mesoderm or secondary mesoderm is formed by the invagination and movement of epiblast cells between the newly formed endoderm and the epiblast. 

In the later stages of development, the ectoderm and endoderm mostly persist as lining epithelium. Mesoderm forms most of the tissues of the body, including bone, cartilage, connective tissue, muscles (skeletal, smooth, cardiac), blood, lymph, and cardiovascular organs.

questions.text: A young woman with fever and lower abdominal pain is diagnosed to have PID. Which is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of PID.

PID is an infection of the upper genital tract. It is generally transmitted sexually as an ascending infection along with sperms. It is usually a polymicrobial infection,

Organisms causing PID include:

Sexually transmitted:

  • Chlamydia (most common)
  • Gonococcus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Trichomonas

Pyogenic Aerobes:

  • Staphylococci
  • Streptococci
  • E Coli

Anaerobes:

  • Bacteroides fragilis
  • Peptostreptococcus 
  • Clostridium 
  • Actinomyces (most common in IUD users)

Other: 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Note: Genital tuberculosis is the only PID that does not spread sexually. It has a hematogenous spread. Thus, it is the most common PID in virgin girls.

questions.text: The vascular lesion shown below is not  seen in
questions.solution:
This vascular lesion is seen in hyaline arteriosclerosis, not polyarteritis nodosa.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis, the vascular lesion associated with hypertension is both more prevalent and more severe in diabetics than in nondiabetics. It may be seen in older nondiabetics without hypertension.

It takes the form of an amorphous, hyaline thickening of the wall of the arterioles, which causes narrowing of the lumen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the pupillary light reflex pathway?
questions.solution:
The lateral geniculate body is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway. It is part of the accommodation reflex and the visual pathway.

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First neurons (sensory) connects each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi.
  • Second neurons (internuncial) connects each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion.
  • Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leaves the ciliary ganglion and passes in the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.

Image: Pupillary reflex pathways

questions.text: Which is the culture method shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
Streak culture is the culture method shown in the above image. It is the most commonly used method for culture in microbiology. It is done by streaking the agar plate with a wire loop.

The other methods of culture are:

  • Lawn culture: used for antimicrobial susceptibility testing. 
  • Stroke culture: used for biochemical tests inoculation. 
  • Stab culture: used for maintaining stock cultures.
  • Liquid culture: used for blood culture.
  • Pour plate culture: quantitative method, used for estimating viable bacterial count.

The above discussed methods are aerobic culture methods

questions.text: What type of tympanogram would you expect to see in a patient with serous otitis media?
questions.solution:
B-type tympanogram is expected in a case of serous otitis media.

Here, compliance decreases i.e., mobility of tympanic membrane is restricted due to the effusion, usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (eustachian tube obstruction). This results in a B-type tympanogram. 

Hearing tests suggestive of conductive hearing loss as seen in serous otitis media:

  • Rinne negative (BC>AC).
  • Weber - lateralized towards the worse ear
  • Audiogram - AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
  • Impedance audiometry - flat curve (reduced compliance, shift to the negative side)

Note: Tympanograph is Flat when there is Fluid in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse, which is not seen in left-sided heart failure.  

Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.

The various causes of the collapsing pulse include

  • Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance. 
  • Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva
  • High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism)

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman complains about throbbing pain over both palms. Her examination findings and lab reports are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 11 g/dL

WBC - 9,000 /mm3

Platelet count - 7,00,000 /μL

Bone marrow biopsy - hypercellular with megakaryocytes and reticulin fibrils

Philadelphia chromosome - absent

MPL mutation - positive
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The image showing erythematous hands is suggestive of erythromelalgia.

Essential thrombocythemia (essential thrombocytosis) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is associated with mutations that increase JAK-STAT signaling.

WHO criteria for diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia:

  • Major criteria -
    • Platelet count ≥450 × 109/L
    • Bone marrow biopsy showing proliferation mainly of the megakaryocyte lineage with increased numbers of enlarged, mature megakaryocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei
    • Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 chronic myeloid leukemia, PV, PMF, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms
    • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation
  • Minor criteria - the presence of a clonal marker or absence of evidence for reactive thrombocytosis

Diagnosis of ET requires meeting all 4 major criteria or the first 3 major criteria and the minor criterion

Option A: Polycythemia vera can also present with erythromelalgia. However, it also presents with increased Hb levels. 

Option C: Fibrosis (not reticulin fibrils) is seen in bone marrow biopsy of primary myelofibrosis. 

Option D: WBC counts are increased in leukemoid reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Factories Act?

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.solution:
Factories act prohibits children of <14 years from being employed.

Children between 15–18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM–7 PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.

The maximum working hours for an adult industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day; if overtime is paid, then it should be not more than 60 hrs per week.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a phospholipid?
questions.solution:
Ceramide is not a phospholipid.

Ceramide consists of sphingosine and a fatty acid (ceramide = sphingosine + fatty acid) . It can be a component of a phospholipid e.g sphingomyelin, which consists of ceramide, phosphoric acid and choline. It is also a component of non-phosphorylated compound lipids like cerebrosides, globosides, and gangliosides. These are fatty acids esterified with alcohol and contain other groups.

Option A: Plasmalogens are a class of glycerophospholipids that contain vinyl-ether.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented to the physician with complaints of heartburn and a sour taste in the mouth for the past 1 year. He was prescribed proton pump inhibitors, but the symptoms did not improve. What is the immediate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of dyspepsia not responding to PPIs. So the best management for this patient is endoscopy.

In case of an unexplained dyspepsia

  • If the patient is >60 years - Endoscopy is the investigation of choice 
  • If the patient is <60 years - A test for H.pylori infection is done (stool antigen and urease breath test) and eradication treatment is given. Endoscopy is done only if any one of the alarming signs are present.

Alarming signs

  1. Odynophagia or dysphagia
  2. Unexplained weight loss
  3. Massive GI bleeding
  4. Recurrent vomiting
  5. Jaundice
  6. Palpable mass or adenopathy
  7. Family history of GI malignancy

questions.text: Staphyloma involves ______.
questions.solution:
Staphyloma (a bunch of grapes) is a clinical condition characterized by ectasia (dilation or bulging) of the outer coats (cornea or sclera or both) of the eye with the incarceration (trapping) of the uveal tissue.

The image given below shows the anatomical types of staphyloma.

The above image shows an anterior staphyloma.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis is the prior use of antibiotics.

Some proportion of patients with endocarditis have negative blood cultures. The important causes are:

  • Prior antibiotic use (most common cause)
  • IE due to fastidious organisms or unusual pathogens or fungi such as:
    • Streptococci (Granulicatella and Abiotrophia species)
    • HACEK organisms
    • Coxiella burnetii
    • Bartonella species
    • Brucella
    • Tropheryma whipplei

questions.text:
Which of the following are oncofetal antigens?
  1. α-fetoprotein
  2. Carcinoembryonic antigen
  3. Human chorionic gonadotropin
  4. Placental alkaline phosphatase
  5. Immunoglobulins
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are oncofetal antigens.

Alpha-fetoprotein is a valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of the following tumors:

  • Primary hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratomas
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Yolk sac carcinoma
  • Germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumors

Regenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically induced necrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels.

Carcinoembryonic antigen is normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells. It is useful in detection, assessing recurrence, and prognosis of the following tumors:

  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Colorectal carcinoma

CEA levels >5 ng/dL are noted in ascites fluid associated with malignancy. Canalicular pattern for polyclonal CEA more sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, metastases in pancreatic adenocarcinoma and not sensitive for metastasis in bile duct adenoma.

Elevated levels are also present in the following non-neoplastic conditions:

  • Cirrhosis
  • Biliary obstruction
  • Hepatitis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Smokers
  • Post-surgical bowel sequestration
  • Mucocele
  • Benign cysts may be positive for carcinoembryonic antigen

questions.text: What is the adult representation of the location of anterior neuropore?
questions.solution:
The location of the anterior neuropore is represented in adults as lamina terminalis. 

The anterior neuropore closes around the 25th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the lamina terminalis. The lamina terminalis forms the anterior boundary of the third ventricle.

The posterior neuropore closes around the 28th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the terminal ventricle. The terminal ventricle is present in the proximal 5 to 6 mm of filum terminale.

questions.text: During routine USG examination of a G2P1L1 woman, you note findings suggestive of placenta increta. What is the pathology involved in this condition?

choices.text: Villi are attached to lower uterine segment

questions.solution:
In placenta increta, the chorionic villi invade the myometrium.

Accrete syndromes or morbidly adherent placenta describe the abnormally implanted, invasive or adhered placenta. These occur due to:

  • Partial or total absence of the decidua basalis 
  • Poor development of the Nitabuch layer.  

The various types of morbidly adherent placenta are:

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta

(most common)  

Villi are attached to the myometrium

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

 

Note: Villi are attached to the lower uterine segment in placenta previa.

 

Investigations that help in diagnosing these conditions:

  • USG
  • Color Doppler 
  • MRI 

 

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta:

  • Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between uterus and placenta
  • Placental vascular lacunae
  • Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

 

The image below shows placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

questions.text: Blood cultures drawn from a late preterm baby on day 8 of life show the growth of streptococcus species within 18 hours. An umbilical line tip culture also shows the same bacteria. Which among the following is the most common manifestation of the described type of neonatal sepsis?
questions.solution:
Bacterial growth in the umbilical tip and blood cultures on day 8 suggests a hospital-acquired infection after 72 hours. This is late-onset neonatal sepsis. 

The most common manifestation of late-onset neonatal sepsis is meningitis.

  Early-onset sepsis Late-onset sepsis
Presentation Presents within first 72 hours of life Presents after 72 hours of life
Source of infection Maternal genital tract Nosocomial or community-acquired
Manifestation Respiratory distress and pneumonia Septicemia, pneumonia, or meningitis

 

NOTE:

Traditionally, neonatal sepsis had been classified as EOS (<7 days) and LOS (>7days), but recently, experts have come to believe that Early-onset neonatal sepsis manifests within the first 72 hours of life and Late-onset neonatal sepsis after 72 hours of life.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of severe pain and numbness in his calf muscles following morning walks. The symptoms subside on taking rest. On examination, thickened toenails, decreased pulses, and reduced temperature of the legs are noted. He has a history of smoking for the past  20 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes intermittent claudication. It is the most common symptom of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The most appropriate advice for this patient is antiplatelet therapy with aspirin.

PAD occurs due to atherosclerotic plaques causing stenosis and occlusion of blood flow. The symptoms of inadequate blood flow exacerbate during increased physical activity.

The following advice is given to patients with PAD:

  • Lifestyle modification- regular exercise, discontinue smoking
  • Statins to treat hypercholesterolemia
  • Reducing the risk of cardiovascular events:
    • Controlling hypertension- angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, beta-blockers
    • Antiplatelet therapy- aspirin, clopidogrel
  • Revascularization procedures (catheter-based or surgical)- For patients not improving with medical therapy
    • Endovascular interventions- percutaneous transluminal balloon angioplasty (PTA), stent placement, atherectomy
    • Surgical- aortobifemoral bypass using Dacron grafts, axillofemoral bypass, femoro-femoral bypass

Antiplatelet therapy and warfarin is not preferred because of the high risk of bleeding.

Intravenous heparin is used to treat acute limb ischemia which most often occurs due to thromboembolic events. Acute limb ischemia presents with loss of pulses distal to the occlusion, cyanosis, or pallor. These symptoms do not subside on taking rest. Hence, this patient has intermittent claudication and not acute limb ischemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state with complaints of bleeding PV  associated with abdominal pain and a history of amenorrhoea for 8 weeks. On examination, BP was 90/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and UPT was positive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy which must be immediately managed with simultaneous resuscitation and laparotomy. On laparotomy, salpingectomy is the definitive surgery. 

Diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made based on clinical features:

  • Amenorrhoea for 6-8 weeks followed by bleeding PV
  • Abdominal pain 
  • Hemodynamically unstable 
  • Urine pregnancy test - positive

Surgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy includes salpingectomy or salpingostomy, performed either through laparoscopy or laparotomy.

Management of suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy consists of initial resuscitation and stabilization, followed by point-of-care ultrasound (FAST) to identify intraperitoneal free fluid and surgical exploration. 

Laparotomy is done for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingectomy is the treatment of choice and is done with preservation of the ipsilateral ovary and its vascular supply. 

For patients wishing to preserve future fertility, if the contralateral fallopian tube is damaged, salpingostomy is preferred. However, salpingostomy may result in inadequate evacuation of the products of conception and a recurrence of symptoms. Therefore, after a patient undergoes salpingostomy, it is important check the β-hCG level on a weekly basis to ensure that it reaches zero.

The image given below shows a laparoscopic visualization of a tubal pregnancy.

questions.text: A positive Troisier’s sign refers to the involvement of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Troisier’s sign refers to the enlargement of left supraclavicular lymph nodes, which is also known as Virchow nodes. It is seen in patients with gastric cancer metastasis, caused by the spread of the tumor via the thoracic duct into the left supraclavicular lymph nodes. It is a sign of advanced cancer.

It is one of the atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma. Other atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma include

  • Sister Mary Joseph nodule
    • Due to periumbilical metastasis. 
    • See in both gastric cancer (most common) and ovarian cancer.
  • Krukenberg’s tumor
    • Bilateral ovarian metastasis
    • Due to retrograde lymphatic spread
  • Irish nodule
    • Left axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Blumer shelf nodules
    • Pelvic metastasis into the pouch of Douglas/ retrovesical pouch
    • Sign of advanced gastric carcinoma 
    • Felt on digital palpation
  • Trosseau syndrome
    • Migratory thrombophlebitis
  • Leser Trelet sign
    • Multiple seborrheic keratoses
    • Resolves after gastrectomy
  • Tripe palms
    • Hyperkeratosis palm.

The image below shows an elderly man with left supraclavicular lymph nodes enlarged.

questions.text: Millennium Development Goals were based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Millennium Development Goals were based on the United Nations Millennium Declaration. 

The Millennium Development Goals were eight development goals to be achieved by 2015 and were established at the turn of the millennium in 2000 by the UN.

It came to an end in December 2015 and was replaced by the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

On 1st January 2016, the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 agenda officially came into force.

The five P's of the new agenda are: 

  • People
  • Planet
  • Prosperity
  • Peace
  • Partnership

The eight Millennium Development Goals are:

questions.text: Which of the following is observed during sleep induction?
questions.solution:
The cholinergic neurons in pontine reticular formation on stimulation, induce sleep.

When the activity of norepinephrine and serotonin containing neurons (locus coeruleus and raphe nuclei) is dominant, there is a reduced level of activity in acetylcholine-containing neurons in the pontine reticular formation leading to wakefulness. The reverse of this pattern leads to REM sleep. A more even balance in the activity of these groups of neurons is associated with NREM sleep.

Related Pearl: Neurochemical changes in Sleep-Wake Cycle

questions.text: A medical student receives a booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccination. A few hours later, she develops weakness in the abduction and lateral rotation of that arm. Which nerve is most likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve or surgeon's nerve is frequently injured during inadvertent intramuscular (IM) injections. 

The course of axillary nerve:

  • It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus in the axilla
  • It exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm
  • In the arm, it winds around the surgical neck of the humerus and gives cutaneous supply to the lower part of the deltoid (upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm)

Injuries to the axillary nerve can be caused by:

  • Fracture of surgical neck of humerus
  • Inferior dislocation of the humerus
  • Inadvertent IM injection

Test for axillary nerve involves testing sensations of skin over the lower part of the deltoid. In the case of axillary nerve lesions, there is a loss of sensations over this region. It is called regimental badge anesthesia.

Named nerves of the upper limb are:

  • Laborer’s nerve - median nerve
  • Musician’s nerve - ulnar nerve
  • Surgeon’s nerve - axillary nerve
  • Nerve of Bell - long thoracic nerve

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with 2 weeks of productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. A chest radiogram was done as shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for him?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has a lung abscess, as the chest X-ray shows an air-fluid level. Clindamycin is the drug of choice for treating lung abscesses.

Chest X-ray showing lung abscess(yellow) with air-fluid level (arrow):

Clindamycin is preferred over penicillin for primary lung abscesses (caused by aspirating oral flora in healthy individuals) due to its effectiveness against β-lactamase-producing anaerobes. Recommended treatments include IV clindamycin followed by oral clindamycin or a β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combination like amoxicillin-clavulanate. Therapy continues until imaging confirms resolution. Metronidazole alone is ineffective since it does not cover microaerophilic streptococci.

Secondary lung abscesses (caused by underlying conditions like malignancy, immunosuppression, or bronchial obstruction) are treated by targeting the identified pathogen and prolonging antibiotic courses based on the patient’s immune status. If no improvement is seen in 7 days, further evaluation is needed to rule out underlying causes.

Large abscesses (>6–8 cm) are less likely to resolve without additional interventions, such as drainage or surgery. Patients who fail antibiotic therapy, especially if they are poor surgical candidates, may require surgical resection or percutaneous drainage. Possible complications of drainage include pleural infection, pneumothorax, and hemothorax.

Note: Pneumatoceles are thin-walled cavities in the lung parenchyma that are seen in respiratory tract infections. They are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus in children and Pneumocystis jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. Below is the chest X-ray showing a pneumatocele.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. The swelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is a gurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.

Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition.

Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years.

Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.

questions.text: Which is the most common cardiac rhythm seen in adults experiencing sudden cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
The most common cardiac rhythm seen in adults experiencing sudden cardiac arrest is asystole, as recorded at initial contact in 45–50% of cases.

Previously VF was thought to be the common rhythm, but its incidence has now been decreasing.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: A woman with menorrhagia is diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Prior to starting treatment, you want to check if she is premenopausal. On which day of the menstrual cycle will you estimate her FSH levels?

choices.text: On day 2-5 after last menstrual period
On day 11-14 after last menstrual period

questions.solution:
The follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) level is studied on day 2–5 after the last menstrual period to detect the premenopausal stage.

It is a period of 3–4 years before menopause and is associated with mild ovarian hormonal deficiency leading to menstrual disorders, especially menorrhagia.

The climacteric phase is the phase of waning of ovarian activity. It begins 2 to 3 years before menopause and may continue 2-5 years after menopause. It marks the transition from active to inactive ovarian function and involves physical, sexual, and psychological adjustments.

The predictors of approaching menopause include:

  • A fall in the level of inhibin B and a corresponding rise in FSH level
  • A fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) - This is a better marker of ovarian reserve and can be tested on any day of the cycle.

questions.text: A term neonate born by vacuum-assisted delivery developed mild respiratory distress 1 hour after birth. Arterial oxygen saturation remained > 95% without supplemental oxygen. Chest radiography performed 6 hours after birth is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph showing a spinnaker sign is suggestive of pneumomediastinum.

Spinnaker sign (also called angel wing sign) is a radiographic sign seen in neonates with pneumomediastinum. Pneumomediastinum is the presence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum. The pressure from the collected gas displaces the two lobes of the thymic tissue upward and laterally from its normal position. This results in large, wedge-shaped opacities on radiograph resembling the spinnaker headsails of a boat.

This should be distinguished from a thymic sail sign which is a normal finding on a neonatal chest x-ray. It represents a physiologically enlarged thymus in a neonate.

Other signs of pneumomediastinum are:

  • V sign of Naclerio - It is due to a V-shaped air collection. One limb of the V is produced by mediastinal air outlining the left lower lateral mediastinal border and the other limb is produced by air between the parietal pleura and medial left hemidiaphragm.
  • Continuous diaphragm sign - Normally the central portion of the diaphragm is not discretely visualised on chest radiographs as it merges with the cardiac silhouette. If the diaphragm can be seen continuously across the midline then it is suggestive of free gas within the mediastinum.

The image given below shows the V sign of Naclerio.

The image given below shows continuous diaphragm sign.

questions.text: Which of the following classifications is not used for neck of femur fractures?
questions.solution:
Neer's classification is used for proximal humeral fractures.

Classifications used for neck of femur fracture are:

  • Based on the location of the fracture line
  • Pauwels classification
  • Garden classification
  • Delbet classification (hip fractures in the pediatric population)

Based on the location of the fracture line it can be classified as:

  • Sub-capital - fracture at the junction of head and neck
  • Transcervical - fracture in the neck
  • Basi-cervical - fracture at the base of the neck

 

Delbet classification is used for hip fractures in children. They are grouped into four types based on their location as follows:

  • Type I - Transepiphyseal fracture
  • Type II - Transcervical fracture
  • Type III - Cervicotrochanteric fracture
  • Type IV - Intertrochanteric fracture

Related Pearl: Named classification systems for fractures and dislocations

questions.text: A baby, about 30 days old, is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has large and hazy corneas. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG):

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: At which level does valine enter the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with the following finding. A positive Nagler's reaction confirmed the presence of lecithinase-producing organisms. What is the principle behind this test?
questions.solution:
Nagler’s reaction is an example of a neutralization test. It is done for the detection of lecithinase toxin produced by C. perfringens.

The alpha-toxin of C. perfringens has phospholipase activity. When grown on a medium containing egg yolk phospholipid, an area of opacity around the bacterial colonies is seen (Nagler's positive). The presence of antitoxin can inhibit this.

Other examples of neutralization tests are:

  • Plaque inhibition test- neutralization of bacteriophages 
  • Schick test- neutralization of diphtheria toxin by antitoxin
  • Anti-streptolysin O test- for beta-hemolytic Streptococci.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about diabetic nephropathy is true?

choices.text: Pancreatic transplantation can improve proteinuria at an early stage
Strict glycemic control is unlikely to prevent microalbuminuria
Dietary protein restriction can benefit diabetic patients with albuminuria
Microalbuminuria is not an indicator of long-term cardiovascular morbidity

questions.solution:
Pancreatic transplantation can help improve proteinuria at an early stage. Successful pancreatic transplantation can have the following effects:

  • Prevention of diabetic nephropathy and regression of albuminuria in early stages.
  • Stabilization and improvement of diabetic neuropathy and retinopathy
  • Increase in HDL with reduction in LDL and triglycerides

Option B: Strict glycemic control can prevent or revert microalbuminuria.

Option C: The ADA does not suggest restrictions of protein intake in diabetic patients with albuminuria because studies have failed to prove its benefits.

Option D: Microalbuminuria is an indicator of long-term cardiovascular morbidity.

questions.text: A person complains of severe pain after he fell backwards on his elbow. His X-ray is shown below. What is the preferred treatment in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of the olecranon. Tension band wiring is one of the management methods in this case. 

The Mayo classification divides olecranon fractures into three groups based on fracture displacement and elbow stability. Each group is further subdivided into comminuted or noncomminuted fractures. 

  • Type I - Undisplaced fractures
  • Type II - Displaced but stable fractures
  • Type III - Unstable fractures

Treatment includes:

  • Type I fractures - non-operative management
  • Type II and III fractures - surgery
  • Simple fractures without comminution or instability - tension band wiring, plate fixation, or an intramedullary rod
  • Comminuted fractures and fractures with elbow instability - plate fixation 
  • Osteoporotic patients with significant comminution - excision of the olecranon and triceps advancement

Related Pearl: Tension Band Wiring

A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing.

It is used in:

  • Fracture patella
  • Fracture olecranon 
  • Fracture lateral malleolus
  • Fracture greater trochanter

The below image shows tension band wiring for a fracture olecranon

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Bowen’s disease?

choices.text: Occasionally it may undergo spontaneous partial resolution

questions.solution:
Bowen's disease has a low potential for invasive malignancy. 

It is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma that is characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.

Human papilloma virus infection is associated with it.

Image: Red scaly plaque seen on the finger, in an 81-year-old woman with Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with vague abdominal pain and feeling of a lump in the abdomen for the past 1 year. He was found to have a tumor arising from the stomach on CT scan. Biopsy of the lesion showed tumor cells positive for CD117 and CD34. What is the most likely origin of the tumor?
questions.solution:
The clinical and histopathological features are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

DOG-1 is the recent and most specific marker for Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumour (GIST). KIT (CD117) is the best diagnostic marker of GIST. However, 5-10% of GIST lack KIT expression.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: Decrease in pH shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to_____

choices.text: On either side depending on other factors

questions.solution:
The pH decreasing from the normal value shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the right.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

questions.text: Which of the following does not put a patient at an increased risk for preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Smoking is not a risk factor for pre-eclampsia rather it is protective.

Although smoking during pregnancy causes various adverse pregnancy outcomes, it is associated with a reduced risk for hypertension in pregnancy.

Risk factors for pre-eclampsia are:

  • Previous history of pre-eclampsia
  • Primigravida: young or elderly
  • Family history: Hypertension, pre-eclampsia.
  • Placental abnormalities:
    • Hyperplacentosis: excessive exposure to chorionic villi (molar pregnancy, twins, diabetes)
    • Placental ischemia
  • Thrombophilias: APLA, Protein C, Protein S deficiency, Factor V laden mutation, homocysteinemia
  • Twin pregnancy
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Rh-negative pregnancy
  • New paternity - A new partner for subsequent pregnancies

questions.text: Glass can be sterilized by ______

choices.text: Incineration at 1050 degree Celsius for 5 minutes
Hot air oven at 121 degrees Celsius for 30 – 60 minutes
Autoclaving at 121 degree Celsius for 30 – 60 minutes
Hot air oven at 160 degree Celsius for 120 minutes or less

questions.solution:
• Exposure to dry heat in a sterilizing hot air oven at temperatures of 160° Celsius for 2 hours ensures carbonization of organic material and destruction of microorganisms and spores.
  • This method can be used for metals, glassware, some heat-resistant and/or water-immiscible oils, powders and waxes.

questions.text: A 20-day old baby is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go to the nearby hospital. Which national programme has provisions to benefit this woman to take her baby to the health facility?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.

Assured 18 service guarantees are provided to all pregnant women under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative to provide assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare at no cost and zero tolerance for denial of services for every woman and newborn visiting the public health facility. It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths, morbidities and provide a positive birthing experience.

questions.text: What is the cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornoviruses namely enterovirus 70.

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis also known as "Apollo conjunctivitis" is caused by picornoviruses such as enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus A24. Rarely it is also caused by adenovirus type 11.

It manifests with severe conjunctival congestion, chemosis, subconjunctival hemorrhages, painful follicular conjunctivitis, tearing, lid edema and pre-auricular lymphadenopathy. The cornea may demonstrate a fine punctate keratopathy. The disease is usually self-limiting, running a course of 3-7 days.

The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. 

Enterovirus 71 (Option D) is associated with fatal meningitis, encephalitis, and paralysis. It is also implicated in Hand-Foot-Mouth disease(HFMD) and Herpangia which is papulo-vesiculo-ulcerative rash in oral cavity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with facial weakness and pain for the past 2 days. The following signs are seen on examination. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The features are suggestive of lower motor neuron (LMN) type of facial palsy.

In the image, the absence of wrinkling over the right side of the forehead and incomplete closure of the right eyelid is characteristic of LMN type of facial palsy. 

In upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, the upper part of the face is spared due to bilateral UMN innervation. 

Features of facial nerve palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy of facial muscles Absent Present

Note: Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side due to the action of unaffected facial muscles, while drooping occurs on the affected side.

questions.text: Gap junctions are found in all except ______
questions.solution:
Gap junctions are absent in adult skeletal muscles. 

Gap junctions are intercellular connections with a channel in between. They are present in excitable tissues such as cardiac muscle, smooth muscle and neurons but not in skeletal muscles.

questions.text: You observe the following breathing circuit being used to ventilate a brain-dead patient who is being shifted to the OT for organ procurement. Which type of Mapleson circuit does this belong to?
questions.solution:
The given circuit is the Bain's circuit which is a coaxial modification of the Mapleson D circuit.

Co-axial circuits have two tubings, one inner and one outer tubing (arranged co-axially).

Bain's circuit has

  • Inner inspiratory tubing: carries fresh gas flow to the patient
  • Outer expiratory tubing: carries exhaled gases out through APL (adjustable pressure limiting) valve

Bain's circuit is often called a universal circuit as it can be used for adult and pediatric patients, for spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

Mapleson's D vs Bain's circuit

Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given sign seen?
questions.solution:
The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Smokestack appearance is another pattern of fundus seen in CSR and is a characteristic sign of this condition.

Amsler grid is used for: 

  • Assess macular function and detecting maculopathy.
  • Evaluate the visual field of 10°
  • Good for follow-up in CSR

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the correct sequence of enzymes involved in glycogenolysis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The sequence of enzymes involved in steps of glycogenolysis is phosphorylase, glucan transferase, and glucose-6-phosphatase.

Related Pearl: Glycogenolysis

questions.text: A patient suffering from a methamphetamine use disorder has increased activity of the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Identify the enzyme.
questions.solution:
Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Methamphetamine is a psychostimulant that increases the activity and expression of tyrosine hydroxylase. This causes an increase in the monoamine neurotransmitters including dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

Catecholamines (dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine) are synthesized from tyrosine in the adrenal medulla (chromaffin cells). Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme that catalyzes the hydroxylation of tyrosine to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). This enzyme is abundant in the central nervous system, the sympathetic ganglia, and the adrenal medulla.

The conversion of tyrosine to epinephrine occurs via four sequential steps:

  1. Ring hydroxylation of tyrosine to DOPA: Tyrosine hydroxylase
  2. Decarboxylation of DOPA to dopamine: DOPA decarboxylase
  3. Side-chain hydroxylation of dopamine to form: Dopamine β-hydroxylase
  4. N-methylation of norepinephrine to form epinephrine: Phenylethanolamine-N-Methyltransferase (PNMT)

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: All of the following types of interactions cooperate in stabilizing the tertiary structures of globular proteins except _____.
questions.solution:
Peptide bonds are not involved in stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins. It forms the primary structure of proteins.

Interactions stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins are as follows:

  • Hydrophobic interactions
  • Hydrogen bonds
  • Ionic interactions
  • Disulphide bonds

Note:

Hydrogen bonds and Van der Waal interactions are involved in the formation of α helix (secondary structure).

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the root of the mesentery is false?
  1. It is 30 cm long.
  2. One end is attached to the right sacroiliac joint.
  3. Left ureter and psoas major are crossed by the root of the mesentery.
  4. Superior mesenteric artery and vein are its contents.
  5. It does not cross the midline.
questions.solution:
The root of the mesentery is approximately 15 cm long. It is crossed by the right ureter and right psoas major and it crosses the midline.

The root of the mesentery is the attachment of the mesentery of the small intestine to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs diagonally from the duodenojejunal flexure on the left side of the L2 vertebral body to the right sacroiliac joint. The length of intestinal attachment of the mesentery measures approximately 5 to 6 meters (same as the length of the small intestine) and it has a breadth (from the root to the intestinal border) of 20 cm.

Structures crossed by the root of the mesentery include:

  • Third part of the duodenum
  • Abdominal aorta
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right ureter
  • Right psoas major

Contents of the mesentery include:

  • Superior mesenteric vessels (jejunal and ileal branches)
  • Nerves related to the superior mesenteric plexus
  • Lymphatics and regional lymph nodes
  • Connective tissue and fat

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman presents to the antenatal clinic at 24 weeks for a routine check-up. USG shows a normal for gestational age fetus in frank breech position, with no other abnormalities. What is the next best step in ​management?
questions.solution:
75gm oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is the most appropriate next step of management. The screening strategy for detecting gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) recommends performing blood glucose testing at 24-28 weeks in case of average risk.

Breech presentation at 24 weeks is not a cause for concern because it can spontaneously rotate and becomes cephalic at term. Hence, external cephalic version (ECV) and immediate caesarean section are not indicated at this time.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
100-day glaucoma is a neovascular glaucoma that occurs in ischemic type of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

It is known as 100-day glaucoma because it occurs 3 months after the episode of CRVO. Although neovascular glaucoma occurs as a complication in Eale's disease (Option B) and central retinal artery occlusion (Option C) and long-term use of topical steroid therapy causes steroid-induced glaucoma (Option D) none of them are termed as 100-day glaucoma.

CRVO is further classified into two types:

  • Non-ischemic CRVO: occurs secondary to venous stasis.It is the most common type of CRVO of the two.
  • Ischemic CRVO: occurs due to acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is also termed as hemorrhagic retinopathy.

Ischemic CRVO presents with sudden loss of vision and Relative afferent pupil defect(RAPD).

Fundus examination shows massive enlargement of retinal veins and massive retinal hemorrhages giving a "splashed tomato appearance". Other findings include cotton wool spots, optic disc edema and neovascularization at the disc and in the periphery.

Pathagnomic features of ischemic CRVO that differentiates it from non-ischemic CRVO are:

  • RAPD
  • Reduced amplitude of B-wave on electroretinogram
  • Visual field defects

Complications of the disease:

  • Neovascular Glaucoma known as 100 day glaucoma
  • Neovascularisation of iris known as Rubeosis iridis
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Proliferative retinopathy

The below-given fundus image is of the "splashed tomato" appearance of CRVO. 

Option B: Eales disease is an idiopathic inflammatory disease of the peripheral retinal veins.It is considered to be a hypersensitivity reaction to the tubercular proteins and it is commonly seen in young males. It is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhage.

Complications include:

  • Neovascular glaucoma
  • Proliferative vitreoretinopathy
  • Tractional retinal detachment,
  • Rubeosis iridis

Option C: Central retinal artery occlusion(CRAO) is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. It presents as sudden painless loss of vision and amaurosis fugax (transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia). Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot.

Neovascular glaucoma may occur as a delayed complication of CRAO but it is not termed as 100 day glaucoma.

The below image depicts the fundus image seen in CRAO with the cherry red spot.

Option D:Steroid induced glaucoma is a type of secondary open angle glaucoma that usually follows weeks-months of topical steroid therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in peristalsis by causing relaxation?
questions.solution:
The release of NO and VIP (Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) from the cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction relaxes the segment of the intestine ahead of the stimulus.

Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food.

Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of intestine.

Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which causes relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of a bolus of food.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensives are not used in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker and is not safe for use during pregnancy.

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBS
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside

Antihypertensives found to be safe in pregnancy:

  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardioselective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: may be used as a last choice

questions.text: Which of the following hearing defects is not seen in otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Presbyacusis is not seen in otosclerosis.

The following hearing defects are seen in otosclerosis:

  • Painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss most commonly.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss may be seen in cochlear type of otosclerosis.
  • Paracusis willisii: Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard.

questions.text: Chandlers Index is used in epidemiological studies of_____
questions.solution:
Chandlers index is used to identify the importance of hookworm infestation as a public health problem in a community. It is calculated based on the average number of hookworm eggs/gram of stool:

  • <200: no significance
  • 200-250: the potential danger
  • 250-300: minor public health problem
  • >300: major public health problem

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV serotypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with carcinoma cervix.

Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include:

  • Human Papilloma virus (most important)
  • Sexual intercourse before 18 years
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Multiparity
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Smoking and drug abuse
  • Women with STD, HIV, HSV 
  • Immune suppression

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV DNA detection.

questions.text: Which of the following practices is covered under the COPRA act?
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights.

It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are:

  • Right to safety
  • Right to be informed
  • Right to be heard
  • Right to choose
  • Right to seek redressal
  • Right to consumer education

questions.text: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presents with features suggestive of HELLP syndrome. Which of the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Corticosteroids aid in increasing platelet count
It is characterised by microangiopathic hemolysis
MgSO4 can be used in the management of HELLP syndrome
Termination of pregnancy is the definitive management

questions.solution:
Corticosteroid treatment for thrombocytopenia is not recommended in patients with HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is a serious complication in pregnancy characterized by HEmolysis, ELevated liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count. It occurs in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies and in 10–20% of patients with severe preeclampsia.  

Management of HELLP syndrome is supportive, including:
- Antiseizure prophylaxis with MgSO4
- Platelet tansfusion if platelet count <50,000/mm3 , FFP transfusion
- Plasmapheresis
- Immediate termination of pregnancy in the interest of the mother.

 The most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is abruptio placenta and DIC.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents with reports showing fungal pneumonia, the causative organism is shown below. Parents give a history of recurrent bacterial infections. Laboratory analysis show markedly elevated IgM and low levels of IgG. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his illness?

IgM: Immunoglobulin M

IgG: Immunoglobulin G

STAT 3: Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3

NADPH: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate

choices.text: Defective cytokine signaling in T-cell precursors
Autosomal-dominant mutation in the STAT3 gene
Deficiency in CD40 ligand or CD40
Defect in the NADPH oxidative pathway

questions.solution:
The given history of recurrent bacterial infections and fungal pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii (as shown in the image above), along with elevated IgM and low IgG levels, are suggestive of hyper-IgM syndrome, an inherited deficiency in the CD40 ligand or CD40.

Hyper-IgM syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency disorder that is inherited as:

  • X-linked form (most common): CD40 ligand (CD40L) defect on T-helper cells, preventing B-cell activation, class switching and memory cells formation. 
  • Autosomal recessive form: Affect CD40 on B-cells or enzymes like activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), a DNA-editing enzyme expressed in B cells. 

The B-cell response to T-independent antigen is unaffected. CD40–CD40L interactions are also required for IL-12 secretion. So, defects in this pathway result in increased susceptibility to intracellular pathogens.

In normal immune response, B-cells expressing CD40 on their surface interact with CD40L on T-cells to undergo class switching from IgM to various other classes (IgG, IgA, IgE) depending on the type of antigen. Thus, failure of this class switching leads to an increase in IgM with extremely low levels of IgG and no IgA or IgE. 

Clinical features include recurrent pyogenic infections caused by low levels of opsonizing IgG antibodies. Patients are highly susceptible to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

The illustration below depicts the defects in components of T-cell & B-cell interactions that give rise to primary immunodeficiency.

Other options: 

Option A: Defective cytokine signalling in T-cell precursors is seen in X-linked Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID). It is caused by a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. This defect disrupts Interleukins (IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-15 and IL-21) signalling, leading to low T-cell and NK-cell numbers. Although B-cell numbers are normal, these are non-functional due to the absence of T-cell help, resulting in impaired antibody synthesis. 

Option B: Mutation in the STAT3 gene is seen in an autosomal dominant form of Hyper IgE syndrome (also known as Job syndrome), characterized by recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent pulmonary infections often with pneumatoceles and atopic dermatitis. Here, serum IgE levels are markedly elevated (due to IgE overproduction without modulation), and IgA, IgG and IgM concentrations are generally normal. 

Option D: A defect in NADPH oxidative pathway is seen in chronic granulomatous disease, leading to failure of the oxidative burst in phagocytes, predisposing individuals to catalase-positive microbial infections.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with headache, seizures, and focal neurological deficit. Imaging shows a tumor in the right frontal lobe which crosses the midline and the histological section of the resected tumor is shown below.  Which of the following molecular subtypes does this tumor belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histological image are suggestive of primary glioblastoma, IDH - wild type.

The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which are characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme). 

According to the WHO classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:  

1. Glioblastoma, IDH - wild type:

    • About 90% of the cases
    • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
    • Over 55 years of age

2. Glioblastoma, IDH - mutant type:

    • About 10% of the cases
    • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
    • Arises in younger patients

3. Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed. 

World Brain Tumor Day is celebrated on 8th June annually.

questions.text: In a rice processing factory, paddy is soaked in hot water.  After this, the water is drained and the paddy is steamed and dried. Which of the following statements is false about the above process?

choices.text: This method is used for partial cooking of rice
It makes the rice grains resistant to insects
Vitamins and minerals are driven into endosperm during this process

questions.solution:
The procedure mentioned above is parboiling. It hardens the rice grains.

Parboiling is the process of partial cooking of rice in steam. It is done by the hot soaking process that was initially developed by the Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysore.

The advantages of parboiling are:

  • Preserves nutritive quality by driving the vitamins and minerals into the endosperm.
  • Hardens the grains and makes them insect resistant.

questions.text: Which of the following cytogenetic changes suggest a favorable prognosis in patients with acute myeloid leukemia?

choices.text: t (11q23;v) with diverse MLL fusion genes

questions.solution:
Normal karyotyping with mutated NPM indicates a favorable prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

questions.text: A teenager presents to the dermatologist with the following finding. Which of the following is not a causative factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
A teenager presenting with papulopustular lesions on the face and the presence of comedones is most likely suffering from acne vulgaris. Oily skin due to excessive sebum production is one of the causative factors of acne, but oily food is not directly implicated

Acne results from the combination of:

  • Increased sebaceous gland activity under the influence of androgens - oily skin
  • Abnormal follicular differentiation with increased keratinization- hypercornification of duct due to increased IL-1
  • Microbial hypercolonization of the follicular canal leading to its inflammation.

questions.text: An elderly gentleman presents to you with complaints of forgetfulness. He is unable to work as his memory issues were causing him distress, and he has difficulty concentrating. He also has insomnia, depressed mood, loss of appetite, and fatigue for the past two weeks. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario of an elderly depressed patient with memory loss and dementia syndrome is suggestive of pseudodementia. This syndrome has been termed as dementia syndrome of depression/depression with reversible dementia. The condition may improve or even completely subside after the remission of depression. 

Pseudodementia is a condition that appears similar to dementia but does not have neurological degeneration. Such patients commonly complain of impaired concentration and forgetfulness.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man began to suspect that his wife was cheating on him. He started to follow her and often woke her up in the middle of the night to make accusations, even though she was not having an affair. He even tried to physically harm her because of his suspicions. What is his most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Othello syndrome/morbid jealousy/delusion of infidelity is when the person believes that his/her partner is unfaithful and is cheating on him/her.

This can present as a primary delusional disorder, or it can be a symptom of other disorders like schizophrenia, alcohol-related psychosis, mood disorders, etc.

The Tragedy of Othello, the Moor of Venice, a Shakespearean play, revolves around two characters, Othello and Iago. Othello is a Moorish general who has just married Desdemona, a beautiful and wealthy Venetian. Iago, Othello's jealous and bitter ensign, plans to exploit his master to his own advantage, and maliciously goads Othello until he kills his beloved wife in a fit of blind rage.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.

Types of PPH:

  1. Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH.
  2. Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause.

The risk factors for atonic uterus include:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with _____.
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment. 

A 1:10–1:100 dilution of 5.25%–6.15% sodium hypochlorite (i.e., household bleach) or an EPA-registered tuberculocidal disinfectant has been recommended for decontaminating blood spills.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with bilateral abdominal pain for 3 days and a temperature of 102°F. She also had a mucopurulent vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and a negative urine pregnancy test. Which is the gold standard investigation to confirm her likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is likely to be acute PID. Laparoscopy is the gold standard to confirm acute PID.

Laparoscopy is not done routinely as it is an invasive procedure. It is reserved for only cases where the differential diagnosis is salpingitis, appendicitis, ectopic pregnancy or a case of a non-responding pelvic mass.

The diagnosis of PID is mostly clinical. If diagnosis is unclear, the investigation of choice for PID is USG and culdocentesis.

CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID:

Definitive criteria:

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
  • Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess)
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID

Minimum criteria:

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness

Additional criteria:

  • Oral temperature>38.3C
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate is useful for the management of patients with all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX. Hence, it is not useful for the management of patients with Christmas disease, which occurs due to deficiency of factor IX.

Components of cryoprecipitate are:

  • Factor VIII
  • Factor XIII
  • Fibrinogen
  • Fibronectin
  • Von Willebrand factor

Therefore it can be used in patients with hemophilia A, factor XIII deficiency, hypofibrinogenemia, and von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.

The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).
